questions.text: 40. Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as ____.
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer that has both bladder and bowel involvement but no other distant metastases should be staged as Stage IV A.

Pearl PM1903: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

* A: Microscopic lesion

* A1 - stromal invasion ≤3mm depth

* A2 - a stromal invasion of >3 and ≤5mm depth

* B: Macroscopic lesion

* B1 - stromal invasion >5mm depth & tumor size ≤2cm 

* B2 - tumor size >2cm to ≤4cm 

* B3 - tumor size >4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement

* A1 - tumor size ≤4cm 

* A2 - tumor size >4cm 

* B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina

* B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)

* C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent

* C1: pelvic lymph node involved

* C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

* A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)

* B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: 41. An 11-month-old infant presents with diarrhoea for few days. Which of the following is contraindicated in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Loperamide is contraindicated in this child.

Loperamide is not recommended for use in children younger than 2 years. It is an orally active antidiarrheal agent and increases small intestinal and mouth-to-cecum transit times. It also increases the anal sphincter tone. It is effective against traveller’s diarrhoea and has antisecretory activity against cholera toxin. It is more potent than morphine as an antidiarrheal agent.

The most common side effect is abdominal cramps. Overdose can lead to constipation, CNS depression, and paralytic ileus. The FDA has placed a black box warning on the drug because exceeding the recommended dosage can lead to cardiac events, including torsades de pointes, cardiac arrest, and death.

Other options:

Option B: Racecadotril is efficacious and safe in children with acute diarrhoea. It is an anti-secretory drug that is, is rapidly converted in the body to thiorphan, a dipeptide inhibitor of enkephalinase. Thiorphan inhibits peripheral enkephalin degradation and potentiates the effects of endogenous enkephalins in the gastrointestinal tract to produce an antidiarrheal effect, acting predominantly as an antisecretory agent.

Option C: Zinc acetate as supplementation is now considered a standard part of care, alongside oral rehydration solutions (ORS). Intestinal zinc losses during diarrhea can worsen existing zinc deficiency. This supplementation is effective in reducing both the severity and duration of diarrhea, as well as the risk of persistent diarrhea. Zinc is supplemented as sulfate, acetate or gluconate formulation. The recommended dosage is 20 mg of elemental zinc per day for children over 6 months of age, to be taken for 14 days. 

Option D: Probiotics are preparations containing a variety of bacterial strains that have shown some degree of benefit in acute diarrheal conditions, antibiotic-associated diarrhoea, and infectious diarrhoea. It is not contraindicated in children.

questions.text: 42. A 40-year-old asthma patient complains of a cough with brownish expectoration. He is not responding to his usual therapy for asthma. He has elevated circulating levels of IgE and prominent peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of asthma in this patient, along with cough with brownish expectoration and elevated circulating IgE and eosinophilia, and a chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonisation of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. The risk factors predisposing to ABPA include asthma and cystic fibrosis. There is an obstruction of the bronchioles due to the inflammatory secretions, leading to breathlessness, coughing, and brown sputum casts.

The total circulating IgE and Aspergillus-specific IgE is elevated, and there is peripheral eosinophilia. Chest radiographs may show central bronchiectasis and finger-in-glove signs due to mucous impaction in the airways. The treatment of ABPA is with itraconazole and glucocorticoids.

Other options: 

Option B: Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occur in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species.

Option C: Bronchiectasis is characterised by irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles. Patients have recurrent episodes of cough with copious amounts of sputum, often foul-smelling. Radiographic features include:

* Tramline appearance is seen in chest radiograph

* CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen

* A signet ring sign is seen when the diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery in a cross-section, as shown in the image below.



Option D: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs due to the inflammatory response to the microfilariae. The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough.

questions.text: 43. A 55-year-old male in septic shock requires a central line for vasopressor administration. The intensivist decides to place an internal jugular (IJ) central venous catheter under ultrasound guidance using the Seldinger technique. After inserting the catheter, the most appropriate next step to ensure proper placement and exclude complications is:

choices.text: Obtain a chest X-ray to confirm tip placement
Secure the catheter with sutures and apply a sterile occlusive dressing
Obtain a post-procedure ECG to confirm correct placement based on P-wave changes

questions.solution:
After inserting the catheter, the intensivist should obtain a chest X-ray to confirm tip placement and rule out pneumothorax.

Central Line Insertion includes the following steps.

* Position & Prep – Trendelenburg for Internal Jugular, flat for Subclavian/femoral; use ultrasound to identify the vein and anesthetize the site.

* Needle Insertion – Advance a finder needle under ultrasound, aspirate venous blood, and insert the guidewire.

* Wire Confirmation – Ensure the wire is within the vessel using ultrasound; avoid ectopy by adjusting position if needed.

* Dilatation & Incision – Make a small skin nick, insert the dilator, and expand the soft tissue tract.

* Catheter Insertion – Advance the CVC over the guidewire, remove the wire, then aspirate and flush all ports.

* Secure & Dress – Suture the catheter, place a bio-patch, apply a sterile dressing, and dispose of sharps properly.

* Confirm Placement – Use a chest X-ray (for IJ/SC) to verify tip position in SVC/IVC and rule out complications.

questions.text: 44. A 24-year-old man with breathing difficulty has a flow-volume loop as given below. What is the likely mechanism which can explain the given loop?

choices.text: Variable intrathoracic obstruction due to tracheomalacia
Restriction due to increased lung elastic recoil
Restriction due to chest wall abnormality

questions.solution:
The given flow-volume loop showing a scooped-out pattern suggests obstruction due to airway narrowing such as acute asthma. 

During an episode of acute asthma, there is a narrowing of the small- and medium-sized airways. This occurs due to constriction of the smooth muscles lining the airways and inflammatory thickening of the walls of the airways. Because of this, there is a decrease in the maximal expiratory flow during the later part of the flow-volume curve. This produces the scooped-out or coved pattern seen in the flow-volume loop shown. This obstruction persists despite enhanced expiratory effort but can be effectively treated using β2 agonist agents.

A comparable flow-volume curve pattern occurs in COPD due to early airway closure from loss of elastic support in emphysematous lungs and lower airway inflammation in chronic bronchitis. Similar scooping of the expiratory limb is also observed in bronchiectasis and bronchiolitis.



Any restrictive disease will show a reduction in forced vital capacity (FVC). This is characterized by a smaller flow-volume loop than normal. If the restriction is caused by increased lung recoil (option B), such as interstitial lung disease, there will be a reduction in residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC) as well. RV and TLC usually remain normal if the restriction is caused by chest wall problems (option D).

Variable intrathoracic obstruction (option A) produces a flattening of the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop, while the inspiratory limb remains normal. The pleural pressure is negative relative to the airway pressure during inspiration, which allows air to flow into the lungs normally despite an airway obstruction. However, the pleural pressure becomes positive relative to the airway pressure during expiration, and this worsens the effect of the obstructive lesion in the airways.

questions.text: 45. A patient with advanced Retroperitoneal fibrosis is going to undergo a ureterolysis, a procedure to free the ureter from adhesions. Which of the following is not an anterior relation of the left ureter while exposing it?
questions.solution:
The root of the mesentery is not an anterior relationship of the left ureter.

Ureters are hollow tubular structures responsible for the passage of urine from the pelvicalyceal system to the urinary bladder. They occur as a pair, and each ureter has its own relations:

Anterior relations of the right ureter(abdominal part):

* Descending part of duodenum

* Right colic vessels

* Ileocolic vessels

* Right gonadal vessels

* Root of the mesentery 

* Terminal ileum

Anterior relations of the left ureter(abdominal part):

* Left colic vessels (Option D)

* Sigmoidal vessels

* Left gonadal vessels (Option C)

* Sigmoid mesocolon (Option B)

* Sigmoid colon

The abdominal part of the ureters is posteriorly related to common iliac vessels, psoas major muscles, tips of transverse processes, and genitofemoral nerves, as shown:



The root of the mesentery is around 15 cm and extends from the duodenojejunal flexure(L2 level) to the right sacroiliac joint. It crosses:

* Third part of the duodenum 

* Abdominal aorta

* Inferior vena cava

* Right ureter

* Right psoas major



Ormond disease or Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a condition considered an IgG4-mediated autoimmune disease where there is fibrosis of the retroperitoneal space. The fibrosis often encloses the ureters and leads to renal failure in advanced stages. Late stages may need surgical removal of the ureters from the dense fibrosis, a procedure known as ureterolysis.

questions.text: 46. A histopathological examination of a bone tumor in a middle-aged female is shown below. Which of the following is the recommended mode of treatment in the early stage for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination shows multi-nucleated osteoclast-type giant cells suggestive of giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma. The recommended mode of treatment in the early stage of osteoclastoma is curettage.

Osteoclastoma is a locally aggressive tumor affecting the ends of the long bones (epiphysis), especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. It is seen in patients of the age group 20 to 45 years. It can also occur in conjunction with Paget’s disease of the bone and in association with focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

Patients can present with pain, increasing mass, and pathological fractures. It can extend into the soft tissue and present as a soft tissue mass.

Grossly, it appears as meaty, purplish tissue with soft yellow areas. Histology shows osteoclast-like giant cells along with scattered round and spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. Radiological findings are eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesions with a narrow zone of transition giving it a soap-bubble appearance.

Treatment includes intralesional curettage for stage 1 and 2 lesions, whereas stage 3 lesions are treated with a thorough curettage. Anti-RANKL antibodies such as denosumab can be used to treat advanced stage 3 lesions.

Other options:

Option B: Osteoid osteoma is a small benign tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It most commonly affects diaphyses of long bones such as the femur. Treatment comprises CT-guided radiofrequency ablation, which resolves the symptoms. 

Options C and D: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The preferred method of treatment of osteosarcoma is wide resection and reconstruction. This is mainly owing to the possibility of limb salvage and multi-agent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with agents like doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate. 

Treatment of Ewing's sarcoma includes pre-operative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin, etoposide, and wide surgical excision.

questions.text: 47. A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of amenorrhea 3 months after an abortion. A hysteroscopy reveals intrauterine adhesions. What is most likely to be seen with regard to FSH levels and progesterone challenge in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of amenorrhea after an abortion (likely a dilatation and curettage) with intrauterine adhesions has most likely developed Asherman’s syndrome. FSH levels are normal and no withdrawal bleeding occurs to progesterone challenge in patients with Asherman syndrome.

The presence of intrauterine adhesions is called Asherman syndrome. Destruction of the basal endometrium prevents endometrial thickening, thus no tissue is produced. This leads to amenorrhea despite normal FSH levels and lack of withdrawal bleeding to progesterone challenge. Endometrial damage may follow vigorous curettage in association with PPH, miscarriage, or elective abortion. 

If intrauterine adhesions are suspected radiological evaluation of the uterine cavity is performed.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) shows contrast dye filling an irregulary-shaped endometrial cavity often described as "moth-eaten" appearance.



Saline infusion sonography can be performed as an alternative to HSG. Definitive diagnosis requires hysteroscopy as polyps, leiomyomas, air bubbles and blood clots may masquerade as adhesions.

questions.text: 48. A 46-year-old female patient complains of hot flushes, inability to concentrate, and sleep disturbances. Which among the following would help in the prediction of her approaching menopause?

choices.text: A rise in inhibin B level
A rise in anti-Mullerian hormone level

questions.solution:
A rise in FSH level helps in the prediction of approaching menopause.

Predictors of approaching menopause are:

* A fall in the level of inhibin B. This causes a rise in the FSH level 

* Low ovarian reserve and low antral follicular count are suggested by a fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone. 

* A rise in FSH and a more than normal LH level 

FSH levels are studied on days 2-5 after the last menstrual period. This helps to identify the premenopausal stage.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby, leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45 - 50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhoea. Some of the features include:

* Hot flushes which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2-5 minutes followed by sweating.

* Insomnia, headache

* Dyspareunia

* Irritability, depression, tiredness

* Lack of concentration and lack of memory

Note: Perimenopause is 3-4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhoea.

questions.text: 49. A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. You would report as ______
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 11-14 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs. A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign.

Lambda sign:



Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. There is a single gestational sac with a thin dividing membrane and two fetuses.

Pearl PM2262: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.



 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.



 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.



 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.



 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 



 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.



 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 



 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.



 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.



 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.



 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.

USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.

questions.text:
50. A 65-year-old female patient diagnosed with Stage 3 epithelial ovarian cancer underwent cytoreductive surgery and a course of adjuvant chemotherapy with 6 cycles of Carboplatin + Paclitaxel 4 months ago. She does not have BRCA mutations on evaluation. Her follow-up CA 125 level is 880 U/mL. Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents can be used to manage this patient further?

Normal CA 125 levels: 30-35 U/mL
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of the patient with the rising CA 125 levels is suggestive of Platinum-resistant ovarian cancer, i.e., relapse within 6 months of the Platinum-based chemotherapy regimen. Bevacizumab,  a chemotherapeutic agent, will be used to further manage this patient.

Bevacizumab is the FDA-approved drug for the treatment of platinum-resistant ovarian cancer. The earliest pointer of tumor recurrence is the elevation of CA 125 levels, which may be detected 2-6 months before the disease becomes clinically evident. 

This recurrence of ovarian cancer can be classified as:

Type Patients included  Prognosis/ Management
Platinum-refractory Women who progress during primary chemotherapy Worst prognosis
Platinum-resistant Women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy Slightly better prognosis
Platinum-sensitive Women who relapse more than 6 months after primary therapy Carboplatin + Paclitaxel/ Gemcitabine/ Liposomal Doxorubicin


Non-platinum chemotherapy (Option A and D) is recommended for platinum-refractory and platinum-resistant disease. Bevacizumab has been FDA-approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease. It can also be used in combination with weekly paclitaxel, doxorubicin, and topotecan.

Platinum-resistant patients with germline BRCA 1 or 2 mutations (Option B) can be treated with PARP inhibitors like Olaparib, Niraparib, and Rucaparib (FDA Approved).

Examples of platinum-based drugs include:

* Cisplatin 

* Carboplatin 

* Oxaliplatin 

* Miriplatin

questions.text: 51. A patient under general anesthesia is being monitored with the device shown below. In this device, what should be the recommended value for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Bispectral index technique with frontal EEG leads. In this device, the recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for general anesthesia is 40-60.

The bispectral index is commonly used in clinical practice to assess the depth of anesthesia.

* Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated.

* It utilizes 4 EEG components - Low-frequency waves, high-frequency waves, suppressed EEG waves, and burst suppression.

* The algorithm calculates a number combining all these variables. The lesser the number, the deeper is anesthesia.

* It has numerical values from 0 to 100 with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS.

* Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia- 40-60.

    BIS value    Interpretation
     80-100    Awake
     60-80   Moderate sedation
     40-60 General anesthesia
      <40  Deep anesthesia

questions.text: 52. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after he suddenly started coughing and choking while eating a snack. The parents report that the child became distressed, unable to speak, and appeared to have difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing a radio-opaque object in the right bronchus. Which of the following points represents the V/Q ratio of this child's right lung?
questions.solution:
1 in the graph represents the V/Q ratio of this child's right lung.

The key clinical features in this patient — acute onset of coughing, choking, and laboured breathing — and the radio-opaque object visible on the chest X-ray strongly suggest that a foreign body has become lodged in the right bronchus, causing airway obstruction in the right lung. Point 1 represents V/Q ratio = 0 when ventilation is zero like in this case of foreign body obstruction.

In airway obstruction, there is no ventilation due to obstruction, and the ventilation value becomes zero (V=0), even though perfusion to the alveolus is maintained (Q >0). Hence, the ratio V/Q equals zero (the numerator is zero). In this situation, no gaseous exchange occurs between the capillary blood and alveolar air. 

Ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is defined as the ratio of lung ventilation to the blood flow or the pulmonary perfusion at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. The value of Po2 is 40 mm Hg, and the Pco2 is 45 mm Hg, in normal venous blood.

Other Options:

Option D: At point 4 in the image, If perfusion to the alveolus is blocked by an embolus (Q=0), there will be no gaseous exchange. Here, the alveolar ventilation is still intact (V>0), but there is no blood supply to the alveolus to allow diffusion. Hence the ratio V/Q becomes infinity (the denominator is zero).



Pearl PM0113: Zones of Pulmonary Blood Flow

Zone 1

Zero perfusion

* Does not exist in normal lungs.

* Occurs when the Pulmonary arterial pressure becomes less than alveolar air pressure.

* Pulmonary capillaries become collapsed.

Zone 2

Intermittent blood flow

* This occurs during systole when the pulmonary arterial pressure raises more than alveolar air pressure.

* In normal lungs, this zone occurs from apex to hilum of the lungs.

Zone 3

Continuous blood flow

* Here pulmonary arterial pressure is greater than alveolar air pressure during the entire cardiac cycle.

* In normal lungs, this zone occurs from the middle zone of lungs to base.

questions.text:
53. A 24-week primigravida with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy presents for a routine antenatal visit. Doppler ultrasound reveals the following findings. According to Quintero staging, this would be classified as:

Twin 1: Oligohydramnios (AFI = 3 cm) with no visible urine in bladder, and normal umbilical artery doppler findings.

Twin 2: Polyhydramnios (AFI = 28 cm), and normal umbilical artery doppler findings.
questions.solution:
This case is Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), Quintero Stage II, as evidenced by oligohydramnios along with absent urine in bladder in one twin (donor), and polyhydramnios in the other twin (recipient), along with normal Doppler findings in both.

Quintero staging of TTTS:

* Stage I—discordant amnionic fluid volumes (Polyhydramnios: largest vertical pocket >8 cm in recipient. Oligohydramnios: Largest vertical pocket <2 cm in donor), but urine is still visible sonographically within the bladder of the donor twin (option B)

* Stage II—criteria of stage I, but urine is not visible within the donor's bladder

* Stage III—criteria of stage II and abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein (option D)

* Stage IV—ascites or frank hydrops in either twin (option A)

* Stage V—demise of either fetus

questions.text: 54. A 65-year-old female presents with mild upper abdominal pain and decreased appetite. CT scan revealed a well-circumscribed cystic mass with central calcification and radiating septa giving the sunburst appearance. Fluid aspiration of the cyst revealed low CEA and amylase levels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with mild upper abdominal pain, decreased appetite, low CEA, low amylase levels and well-circumscribed cystic mass with central calcification and radiating septa on CT scan suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Serous Cystadenoma of the pancreas.

Serous cystadenomas are benign tumours and are less likely to be malignant. They are mostly asymptomatic and detected as an incidental finding. Most symptomatic patients have mild upper abdominal pain and epigastric fullness. They can also cause jaundice or gastrointestinal obstruction when they get enlarged. All regions of the pancreas are affected, with half of the lesions in the head and uncinate process and the rest half in the neck, body, or tail of the pancreas. 

A CT scan shows a well-circumscribed cystic mass with small septations, and sometimes, a central scar with calcification can also be seen. The sunburst appearance is seen in 10-20% of patients. Fluid cystic aspiration reveals thin serous fluid that does not stain positive for mucin and has low CEA and amylase levels. Cells, if obtained on aspiration, are cuboidal and have a clear cytoplasm.

It can be either managed conservatively or require surgical resection based on the symptoms produced. 

The CT scan given below shows the serous cystadenoma of the pancreas.



Other options:

Option A: Mucinous Cystadenoma of the pancreas- The cysts have thick walls, and there may be nodules or calcifications within the cyst wall. The cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium and are filled with viscous mucin. Fluid cystic aspiration reveals high CEA and low amylase levels. High levels of CEA is suggestive of a mucinous tumour.

Option C: Pseudocyst- The cyst has no epithelial lining, and the fluid has a high amylase content.

Option D: Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm- They arise within the pancreatic ducts. Diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct can be seen in imaging studies, and the pancreatic parenchyma is often atrophic due to chronic duct obstruction.

questions.text: 55. Alpelisib, in combination with fulvestrant, is approved for the treatment of metastatic hormone-receptor positive, HER2-negative breast cancer. What is the mechanism of action of Alpelisib?
questions.solution:
Alpelisib is a drug that blocks PI3-K, an enzyme vital for cell growth and survival. PI3-K pathways are often overactive in hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer, frequently due to PIK3CA gene mutations. By inhibiting PI3-K, Alpelisib disrupts cancer cell growth signals, promotes cell death, and can overcome resistance to hormone therapies.

Other options: 

Option A) Drugs that target hedgehog pathway are SMO inhibitors (Vismodegib, Sonidegib, Glasdegib) and GLI inhibitor (Arsenic Trioxide).

Option B) MAPK pathway inhibitors include BRAF inhibitors (vemurafenib, dabrafenib, and encorafenib), as well as MEK 1/2 inhibitors (trametinib, selumetinib, and binimetinib).

Option D) Bruton Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors include Ibrutinib, Acalabrutinib, and Zanubrutinib.

questions.text: 56. Rota virus is a __________
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded (ds) RNA virus.

Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. It has 11 segments of double-stranded RNA. They exhibit genetic reassortment due to the presence of this segmented RNA.



Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens.

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a potential risk of intussusception, especially when the first dose of these vaccines is given to infants aged >12 weeks. Because of this risk, the rotavirus vaccine is not a part of catch-up immunization programs.

questions.text: 57. Which among the following is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Mendelsohn maneuver is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation.

Mendelsohn maneuver is a form of supraglottic swallow. It involves voluntarily holding the larynx at its maximum height to prolong the duration of the cricopharyngeal opening. It has been used to treat patients with pharyngeal dysphagia.

Post-laryngectomy rehabilitation aims at establishing communication in a post-laryngectomy patient. Various methods used in these include:

* Written language

* Aphonic lip speech

* Esophageal speech

* Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic device

* Tracheoesophageal speech facilitated by Blom-Singer and Panje prostheses

A transoral pneumatic device is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here, the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

Blom-Singer prosthesis and Panje prosthesis are types of tracheoesophageal prosthesis. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) involves a one-way valve inserted through a previously created tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, the exhaled air is shunted through the TEP into the esophagus, which induces vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter responsible for phonation. It generates the most intelligible, fluent, natural-sounding voice compared to other laryngeal speech methods.

questions.text: 58. A 10-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus. His father suffered a similar condition and passed away last year. What is the most likely electron microscopic picture of his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette with a positive family history is suggestive of Alport Syndrome. The most likely electron microscopy of his renal biopsy is the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.



No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Other options:

Option A: Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases. 

Option C: Epithelial crescent formation is seen in crescentic RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis etc. Features include oliguria and other signs of nephritic syndrome.

Option D: Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is caused due to immune complex deposition of streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies. Clinical features include malaise, oliguria, and hematuria around 1-2 weeks after a streptococcal infection. The urine is typically described as smoky or cola-colored urine.

questions.text: 59. A 50-year-old man with lung cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

Features that point to a diagnosis of dermatomyositis are:

* Image showing - upper eyelid lilac erythema/ heliotrope rash 

* Age group 50-60 yrs

* Proximal myopathy which is manifested as difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, lifting hands, etc.

* Association with internal malignancy (lung cancer)

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

* Facial rash

* Eyelid erythema and edema

* Nail fold changes

* Gottron’s papules

* Shawl sign - macular erythema of the upper chest and back

* Scalp erythema and hair loss

* Flagellate erythema

* Mechanic’s hands

* Poikiloderma

* Cutaneous calcinosis

The following images show Gottron's papules on hand and V-shaped rash over chest, respectively:

questions.text: 60. Which of the following species of Clostridium exhibit swarming growth on agar?
questions.solution:

questions.text: 61. A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of epistaxis while playing cricket. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and earache. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

The above clinical scenario of an adolescent boy of age 12 years presenting with recurrent spontaneous epistaxis, earache, and contrast-enhanced CT scan showing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/ Holman Miller sign) is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumour predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

* Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common

* Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space

* Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube

* Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx

* Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves

Diagnosis: It is mostly clinical. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.



Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumour with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumours with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system. 

Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Treatment: Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolisation of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option A- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumour closely associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection. They are predominantly seen in the fifth to the seventh decade of life. Cervical lymph node involvement, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, nasal discharge, conductive hearing loss with serous otitis media, squint, and diplopia due to involvement of the cranial nerves III, IV, and VI.

Trotter's triad, characterised by conductive deafness, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis may be seen. 

Option C- Inverted papilloma/ Ringertz tumour/ Schneiderian papilloma is the tumour of the non-olfactory mucosa and paranasal sinuses. It is caused due to human papillomavirus. It is more commonly seen in males of the age group 40-70 years. Patients will almost always present with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Orbital invasion can result in proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation. A CT scan shows the location and extent of the tumour.

Below is the CT image showing an inverted papilloma.



Option D- Blow-out fracture is the isolated fracture of the floor of the orbit. The clinical features include ecchymosis of the lid, conjunctiva, enophthalmos, diplopia, and hypoesthesia of the cheek and upper lip. Water's view on radiograph and CT scan shows a characteristic convex opacity bulging into the antrum from above known as the tear-drop sign.

Below is the CT image showing the tear-drop sign of blow-out fracture.

questions.text: 62. A 24-year-old female came in with a complaint of painless lymphadenopathy in the inguinal region. On examination, the patient had a single ulcer in the genital region. Her previous medical documents mention that she is allergic to Penicillin. Which kit would you prescribe to the patient and her partner respectively?

choices.text: White and no treatment to partner
Red and no treatment of partner

questions.solution:
The female has painless lymphadenopathy and a single ulcer, which means the diagnosis is syphilis. Since the patient is allergic to penicillin, she should be treated with a blue kit containing Doxycycline and Azithromycin. 

The first-line treatment for genital ulcer disease, further diagnosed as syphilis, is Penicillin. However, since this patient is allergic to Penicillin, she will be given the blue kit for treatment. Her partner, in this case, should also be treated, as syphilis is highly contagious, and since the partner is not allergic to Penicillin, he should be given a white kit containing injection-benzathine penicillin G and Azithromycin.

Other options:

Option B: A white kit for the patient and no treatment for the partner are incorrect since the patient is allergic to Penicillin and should be given Doxycycline instead of Penicillin. The partner of this patient needs treatment since syphilis is highly contagious.

Option C: Green and White is incorrect since the green kit is used for symptoms of vaginitis and contains drugs Secnidazole and Fluconazole. The patient does not have symptoms of vaginitis but has genital ulcer disease.

Option D: The Red kit is for herpes simplex virus (HSV), which causes painful, multiple vesicular ulcers—not a single painless ulcer.

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: 63. A female patient comes to you with complaints of midline neck swelling. You proceed to perform the thyroid examination and ask her to swallow. The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Pearl PM2397: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

* Parotid gland

* Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

* Common carotid artery

* Internal carotid artery

* Internal jugular vein

* Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: 64. A patient with vocal cord palsy following a history of serious penetrative trauma to neck structures underwent a stroboscopy where both vocal cords were seen to be in a cadaveric position. Which of the following complications is least likely to occur in this condition?
questions.solution:
Stridor is a complication that is least likely to occur in the case of the bilateral cadaveric position of the vocal cords, as seen in bilateral complete palsy. Stridor is seen in B/L recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy where the B/L external laryngeal nerve is spared.

The given clinical scenario describes a patient with a history of extensive penetrative trauma to the neck who, on stroboscopy( video laryngoscopy), shows vocal cords in a bilateral cadaveric/ intermediate position. This implies that the external and recurrent laryngeal nerves are compromised on both sides. In the intermediate position, the cords are in a neutral position(3.5 mm from midline), leaving a space between them.

Such a complication is rare and may occur due to surgical trauma( such as in thyroidectomy), carcinomas of the hypopharynx, larynx, esophagus, metastatic secondaries to lymph nodes( or any other causes of cervical lymphadenopathy), extensive trauma to the neck, etc. Complications in this condition are:

* Aphonia: The patient is unable to speak as resonation of sounds for speech production requires complete closure of the glottis which is not possible in B/L complete palsy. ( Option A)

* Aspiration: As the vocal cords cannot appose tightly, there is recurrent aspiration of secretions and food into the larynx resulting in aspiration pneumonia and recurrent respiratory infections. (Option B)

* Anesthesia: There is a loss of sensation in the entire area supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, further facilitating aspiration of pharyngeal contents.

* Loss of cough: Cough requires a closed glottis and the mechanism of coughing is compromised leading to the inability to clear aspirated food and secretions effectively from the larynx. ( Option D)

Respiratory distress and stridor are generally not seen in such patients as the laryngeal inlet remains perpetually open, facilitating some degree of gaseous exchange. Stridor is a typical feature of B/L RLN palsy where the vocal cords will be in the median/paramedian position completely hampering respiration.

A tracheostomy is still required in B/L complete palsy as clearance of secretions doesn't occur, resulting in recurrent pneumonia if left as it is.

questions.text: 65. The graph shows the rise and fall of cardiac biomarkers in a patient with myocardial infarction. Which of the following statements about the molecule represented by the pink line is untrue?

choices.text: It is part of Light’s criteria
It is a tumour marker in seminomas

questions.solution:
The pink line in the graph showing cardiac biomarkers represents the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase, as evidenced by the delayed peak at 3 days. LDH is a late marker of myocardial infarction. It has five isoenzymes, not three.

LDH or lactate dehydrogenase is an oxidoreductase(Class One) enzyme as per the IUBMB classification of enzymes.(Option A) It catalyzes the reaction: [Lactate+ NAD ⁺ --> Pyruvate + NADH+ H ⁺ ]where NAD ⁺ is reduced by Lactate to NADH+H ⁺ and is itself oxidized to Pyruvate. Hence it is an oxidoreductase enzyme.

LDH has five isoenzymes, LDH 1-5 as summarised below:

Isoenzyme Subunit Tissue of origin
LDH-1 H4 Heart
LDH-2 H3M1 RBC
LDH-3 H2M2 Brain
LDH-4 H1M3 Liver
LDH-5 M4 Skeletal muscle


Normally, LDH-2 is the dominant isoform in serum, but in a patient with myocardial infarction, the LDH-1 isoform becomes elevated, and flipping of the LDH1: LDH2 ratio is highly suggestive of a cardiac insult. LDH starts becoming elevated 6-12 hours after an MI, peaks somewhere at 24- 72 hours from the onset, and returns to normal in 8-14 days.

However, as there are many isoforms of LDH raised in many conditions, it is not specific for myocardial infarction and for this indication, it has been largely superseded by cardiac troponins, which are the preferred markers. Given below is the graph of various biomarkers and their rise after myocardial damage:



Troponin T and I, the preferred biomarkers, rise at around 4 hours, peak in 24- 48 hours, and remain elevated for multiple days. The earliest biomarker to rise is myoglobin, at one hour, peaking at 4- 12 hours and immediately returning to baseline. CK-MB also rises around four hours, peaking at 24 hours and returning to baseline at 48-72 hours.

Other options:

Option C: LDH estimation is a part of Light's criteria for analyzing whether pleural fluid is an exudate or transudate. If any one of the three criteria is satisfied, it is an exudate. Its components are:

*

Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5

* Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6

*

Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds the normal upper limit for serum.

Option D: LDH is a tumor marker for testicular cancers, including seminomas. Its levels correlate with the tumor burden in seminomas and with relapse in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

67. An entrepreneur is starting a factory of 100 employees with 75 males and 25 females. Which of the following must he adhere to according to the guidelines of the WHO Committee on Occupational Health,1953?

1. An obligatory canteen for the employees

2. Installation of drinking water fountains

3. At least 2 washroom facilities

4. Minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per person

5. Pre-placement examination of workers
questions.solution:
2, 4 and 5 are the correct statements.

Installation of drinking water fountains to ensure a sufficient supply of drinking water is a basic requirement in industrial establishments. The use of a common glass tumbler is not preferred as it spreads infection. 

A minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per person is recommended to ensure a comfortable working environment and prevent respiratory infections.

Pre-placement examination of workers at the time of employment ensures the prevention of occupational diseases. The purpose of the examination is to place the right man in the right job so that the worker can perform his duties efficiently without affecting the health of the worker. This is known as ergonomics. 

WHO recommends the following measures for the general health protection of the workers:

* Provide a balanced diet or snacks at a reasonable cost under hygienic conditions

* Control of communicable diseases

* Installation of drinking water fountains

* There should be at least one sanitary convenience for every 25 employees, separately for males and females, for the first 100 employees and thereafter one for every 50

* General cleanliness

* Minimum of 500 cubic feet of space for every worker

* Adequate lighting

* Proper ventilation and temperature 

* Protection against occupational hazards

* Adequate housing facilities for workers near the industry

* Ensure good mental health of the workers

* Special measures for women and children

* Promote health education and family planning

* Pre-placement and periodical examination of workers

Other options:

Statement 1: Under the Indian Factories Act, it is obligatory to provide a canteen when the number of employees exceeds 250.

Statement 3: It is recommended that for the first 100 employees, there should be at least one sanitary convenience for every 25 employees, separately for males and females. For more than 100 employees, there should be one washroom for every 50 employees. Therefore, the entrepreneur should have at least three male washrooms and one female washroom, not just 2 washrooms for the establishment.

questions.text: 68. Which of the following is not a clinical presentation of abusing the substance derived from this plant?
questions.solution:
Magnan syndrome is not a clinical presentation of abusing the substance(cannabis and its derivatives)  derived from Cannabis sativa, the plant shown in the image. Magnan syndrome is characteristic of Cocaine abuse.

The given image shows Cannabis sp., also known as the Hemp plant. It is a tall weed growing up to 15 feet with a typical palmate with deeply sharp-lobed bright green leaves. It is the source of cannabis and its derivatives, a group of deliriant psychoactive substances that contain cannabinol specifically Delta-Tetrahydrocannabinol, the active principle.

The clinical features of intoxication are:

* Low dose: talkativeness, perceptual changes, relaxation, drowsiness, hypertension, tachycardia, slurred speech, excess appetite, postural instability, etc

* High dose: Miosis, conjunctival injection, acute paranoid psychosis, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations, both visual (Option B)and auditory, of a sensual/ erotic nature( hence touted as an aphrodisiac), depersonalization, loss of orientation to time, space.

* Very high dose: Confusion, altered sensorium, pupillary dilation, numb extremities, deep sleep, paralysis, coma, or even death.

Specific manifestations:

* Run Amok: This can develop in chronic use or sudden intake of the drug where the individual has a psychic disturbance marked by depression followed by a sudden frenzied desire to commit murders (Option A). The person develops an abnormal homicidal tendency and may commit murders of individuals with whom he has a real or imagined hostility followed by anyone who is in the way and may finally commit suicide or surrender to the police.

* Cannabinoid Hyperemesis Syndrome(CHS): This is a condition where the abuser exhibits cyclical nausea, abdominal pain, and vomiting(Option C) after consuming cannabis, with typical features of chronic cannabis use spanning years, currently taking cannabis at the time of symptoms and cessation of the condition on stopping drug use. A pathognomonic sign of this condition is that it is relieved by hot showers.

* Amotivational syndrome: A state of chronic drug addiction where the individual has loss of weight and appetite, weakness, tremors, lethargy, apathy, poor concentration, and lack of interest in work.

The various forms of Cannabis substance are:

* Ganja- a resinous material from small leaves and flowering tops with about 25% active principle

* Charas/Hashish dried resinous exudate from flower tops- the purest form and most potent.

* Bhang/Siddhi is a beverage concoction from the mature leaves and stems with the least potency.

* Marijuana/Reef/Pot is any form of the active principle used as a recreational drug in smoked form( with a burnt rope smell), in cakes and foodstuffs, in beverages, etc

* Majoon: Sweet prepared from cannabis.

Option D: Magnan syndrome/Formication/ Cocaine bugs is a tactile hallucination where the addict complains of a feeling of bugs crawling under his skin or sand grains emanating from his skin. It is seen in the chronic consumption of cocaine. Below is an image of the plant from which cocaine is derived, Erythroxylum coca.

questions.text: 71. Which of the following diseases is correctly matched with their enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Hypermethioninemia occurs due to a defect in L-methionine adenosyltransferase.

L-methionine adenosyltransferase converts L-methionine to S-Adenosyl-L-methionine. Subsequent reactions can lead to the formation of propionyl-CoA. The absence of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of methionine. S-Adenosyl-L-methionine is the active form of methionine.

Other options:

Option B: Type I tyrosinemia occurs due to a defect in Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

Option C: Homocystinuria occurs due to a defect in Cystathionine-beta-synthase.

Option D: Alkaptonuria occurs due to a defect in Homogentisate oxidase. Type I phenylketonuria occurs due to defect in Phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: 72. A monoecious leaf-like parasite that passes through two intermediate hosts before infecting man was identified as the causative organism for a patient’s symptoms. Which of the following is not a possible candidate for this parasite?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Schistosoma japonicum cannot be a candidate for a monoecious leaf-like parasite with two intermediate hosts. The question is referring to Trematode Helminthic parasites, of which the genus Schistosoma is an exceptional group of organisms that are dioecious and have only one intermediate host.

Monoecious refers to hermaphrodite, a condition where the male and female sexes are not separate and exist in the same organism. All Trematode Helminths are generally monoecious, a significant exception is Schistosoma. An identification feature is the presence of separate sexes where the male holds the much smaller female in his gynaecophoric canal, a ventral canal on the male body for facilitating mating.

* Acoelomates- they have no body cavity

* Incomplete digestive and nervous systems

* Oviparous- produce eggs, generally operculated(except Schistosoma)

* Monoecious- hermaphrodite

* Leaf-like- dorsoventrally flattened body resembling a leaf

* Three stages in the life cycle- egg, larva, and adult

* Organ of attachment is usually suckers

* Larva has 5 stages: miracidium, sporocyst, redia, cercaria, metacercaria(absent in Schistosoma)

questions.text: 73. The below image shows an implanted human embryo in the second week. Identify the cells that act as immediate precursors for the formation of the intra-embryonic mesoderm among the options labeled 1-4:
questions.solution:
In the given implanted human embryo, among the given options, the cells that act as immediate precursors for the formation of the intraembryonic mesoderm are the Epiblast cells labeled as 2 in the image. Epiblast cells undergo gastrulation and form the intraembryonic mesoderm in the third week.

Shown below is a labeled image of an implanted human embryo. Structures labeled 1-4 in the image are:

* 1: Cytotrophoblast layer

* 2: Epiblast

* 3: Hypoblast

* 4: Heuser's membrane( Exocoelomic membrane)



Implantation occurs at the end of the first week. The implanted human embryo in the second week, also known as the "Week of Twos" undergoes the following developments:

* Trophoblast differentiates into the syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast layers. The syncytiotrophoblast invades the maternal decidual stroma.

* The inner cell mass differentiates into the epiblast and the hypoblast. Together they form the bilaminar germ disc.

* The extraembryonic mesoderm derived from the primitive yolk sac splits into the somatic and splanchnic layers. The somatic layer lines the cytotrophoblast and amnion and the splanchnic layer lines the yolk sac.

* Two cavities are formed: the amniotic cavity and the yolk sac cavity. Amnioblasts are derived from the epiblast and line of the amniotic cavity. Hypoblasts migrate along the exocoelomic membrane in the primitive yolk sac cavity to form the secondary/ definitive yolk sac cavity.

At the end of the second week, there are 3 cavities associated with the embryo: the amniotic cavity, the definitive yolk sac cavity, and the chorionic cavity. The below image of the definitive chorion also shows the three cavities, from above downwards being the amniotic cavity, yolk sac and the chorionic cavity encircling the others.



Gastrulation is the process of establishment of all three germ layers in the embryo in the third week of development. Gastrulation involves the orderly movement of cells in the germ disc. All three layers are derived from the Epiblast. The process is as follows:

* First the primitive streak forms caudally in the germ disc and at its cephalic end the primitive node develops.

* Epiblast cells migrate towards the streak and invaginate into it; some displace the hypoblast to form the endoderm, the first formed germ layer.

* Other epiblast cells come to lie in between the preexisting epiblast and the newly formed endoderm forming the second formed layer, the intra-embryonic mesoderm, which is also derived from the epiblast.

* Cells remaining in the epiblast form the final layer, the ectoderm.

The intraembryonic mesoderm is organized into three parts: the paraxial, intermediate and lateral plate mesoderm, each of which has its unique derivatives during organogenesis.

75. An HIV-positive patient on HAART presents with insomnia, vivid dreams, and dysphoria. After a detailed evaluation, you suspect that the presenting symptoms are due to the adverse effects of an antiretroviral drug. This drug acts at which of the following sites?

HAART- Highly active anti retroviral therapy
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of adverse effects of efavirenz. It acts at site 4, i.e it inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). It is effective against HIV-1 only.

The adverse effects of efavirenz are mainly neuropsychiatric. These include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia. However, these symptoms resolve within the first 4 weeks of therapy and are tolerable.

Other side effects include skin rash, headache, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol.

The illustration given below shows the mechanism of action of various antiretroviral drugs.



Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

Antiretroviral drug Mechanism of action

Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme
Protease inhibitors Inhibits the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from the host membrane.
Entry inhibitors

Interferes with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 into the cell by blocking a target.

Maraviroc works by targetting CCR5, a coreceptor located on human helper T-cells

questions.text: 76. An infant with meconium ileus underwent pilocarpine iontophoresis and had 80mmol/L of chloride in sweat. Repeat testing after two days was also abnormal. What is the usual pattern of inheritance of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where a neonate with meconium ileus underwent pilocarpine iontophoresis and two separate tests showed abnormal elevated chloride levels satisfies the criteria to diagnose the neonate with Cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, as shown in pedigree chart number 2.

In a pedigree chart with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, the disease is manifested only in the homozygous state, both males and females are equally affected, and multiple individuals may be affected in one generation with no affected members in other generations.

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive trait due to a mutation in the CF gene coding for the CFTR pump, a chloride and bicarbonate transport channel expressed in epithelial cells of the aerodigestive and genitourinary systems and the sweat glands on the skin.

The disease is classified into six pathogenic variants based on the type of mutation, variants 1-3 are severe and 4-6 are milder versions. The most common mutation is F508del, the deletion of phenylalanine at the 508th position in the CF gene. Diagnostic criteria for cystic fibrosis satisfies both points:

*  The presence of typical clinical features/ A history of CF in sibling/ A positive newborn screening test

*  Laboratory evidence of CFTR dysfunction in the form of two elevated sweat chloride concentrations obtained on separate days/ identification of two pathogenic CF variants/  abnormal nasal transepithelial potential difference.

Typical clinical features in an infant include recurrent sinopulmonary infections, fetal echogenic bowel, meconium ileus, rectal prolapse, pancreatic insufficiency, dehydration, and hypochloremic hyponatremic metabolic alkalosis. In this infant, meconium ileus prompted a sweat chloride test which was abnormal on two different days, confirming the diagnosis as cystic fibrosis.

Pilocarpine iontophoresis is the standard test done to measure sweat chloride levels. The test involves using an electric current to infuse pilocarpine over the skin of the forearm to stimulate the sweat glands, followed by testing of chloride concentration in the sweat produced. A chloride level of >60mmol/ L is diagnostic of CF in the presence of other criteria.

Newborn screening for CF is done in resource-rich settings with an IRT test- immunoreactive trypsinogen testing in the serum. Immunoreactive trypsinogen is a pancreatic proenzyme that is elevated in nearly all cases of cystic fibrosis in infancy. 

Other Options:

Pedigree Chart 1: It depicts an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance as seen in conditions like achondroplasia.

Pedigree Chart 3: It depicts the X-linked dominant mode of inheritance as seen in conditions like Rett's syndrome.

Pedigree Chart 4: It depicts the X-linked recessive mode of inheritance as seen in conditions like G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: 78. A patient has a defect in class switching of antibodies due to a loss-of-function mutation in CD40 ligand . Which of the following will be a feature of the major antibodies present in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a loss-of-function mutation in the CD40 ligand, the major antibody seen in serum would be IgM. IgM can have a valency of 10 in its pentameric form. 

The given question mentions four statements, each of which is a feature specific to a certain antibody. IgG is the antibody that can cross the placenta ( Option A). The heat-labile antibody is IgE, (Option B) all other antibodies are heat-stable. This implies that IgE is inactivated in one hour at 56 degrees Celcius. The antibody that exists as a dimer joined by the J-chain is IgA (Option C). The antibody with a valency of 10 is IgM.

The valency of an antibody is defined as the number of antigen-binding sites that an antibody possesses, which in turn is determined by the number of subunits it has. IgG, IgD, and IgE are monomers with only two binding sites. Hence, they have a valency of two. IgA is a dimer linked by the J-chain and secretory protein with a valency of four. IgM can exist either as a monomer with a valency of 2 or a pentamer with a valency of 10.

In CD40 ligand defect on the T-cell, other antibodies cannot be synthesized, are deficient in plasma and there is Hyper-IgM syndrome with excess IgM. The most common form of this disorder is an X-linked recessive mutation in the CD40 ligand.

The patient has a loss-of-function mutation in CD40 ligand resulting in the inability of antibodies to undergo class switching. When antibodies are first synthesized by the B-cell, they are all of the IgM variety. B-cells have CD40 receptors that interact with CD40 ligand on the CD4+ T-cell to undergo class switching, a cellular process in which IgM differentiates into the other antibodies. This process is hampered in Hyper IgM syndrome.

Excess IgM can result in hyperviscosity symptoms due to the heavy molecular weight of pentameric IgM. The patient also has recurrent pyogenic infections. Treatment of this condition is supplementation with other antibodies to offset the deficit. Given below is an illustrative table of each antibody and its salient features:



The given image shows the abnormal Bcell-Tcell interaction when the CD40 ligand is defective in Hyper IgM syndrome:

questions.text: 79. Which of the following conditions from the “ Deadly Dozen” can be identified and managed during the secondary survey?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions of the Deadly Dozen, diaphragmatic rupture can be identified and managed in the secondary survey being a potentially life-threatening condition. All other conditions are immediately life-threatening and need to be addressed in the primary survey itself.

The deadly dozen is a term used to describe twelve life-threatening injuries that should be actively sought and managed in the primary and secondary survey due to their potential risk of resulting in patient mortality. They are divided into six, to be identified and managed in the primary survey due to an immediate life-threatening nature, and six to be identified and managed in the secondary survey due to a potentially life-threatening nature. They are:

IMMEDIATELY LIFE-THREATENING

POTENTIALLY LIFE-THREATENING

Airway obstruction

Tension pneumothorax

Pericardial tamponade


Massive haemothorax


Open pneumothorax

Aortic injuries

Tracheobronchial injuries


Myocardial contusion


Rupture of the diaphragm


Oesophageal injuries


 Pulmonary contusion


Diaphragmatic rupture is to be suspected in all penetrating injuries below the fifth intercostal space and injuries involving blunt compressive forces to the abdomen.

It is usually large, often silent in the acute phase until presenting with complications of herniated abdominal contents into the thorax such as strangulation of the viscus. It is occasionally discovered in the operation.

Video-assisted thoracoscopy/ laparoscopy is the best investigation for diagnosis. CXR after NG tube placement may show a herniated stomach in the thorax. CT and USG can act as adjuncts for diagnosis.

Operative repair is preferred and penetrating injuries are approached via the abdomen to rule out hollow viscus injury. The CXR image below shows the raised right hemidiaphragm in a case of rupture to the diaphragm.



Pearl PM2499: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

* Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient

* Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries

* Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

* Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.

* Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated

* Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.

* Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels

* Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

* Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match

* ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis

* Urinary and gastric catheters

* Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.

* (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: 80. A girl presents with concerns about her 56-year-old father’s behaviour. She reports he has become apathetic and aggressive for the past 2 months. His personal hygiene has declined but his memory is quite intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Frontotemporal dementia.

Frontotemporal dementia, also known as Pick disease, is characterised by atrophy in the frontotemporal regions. These regions also have neuronal gliosis, loss and neuronal Pick bodies, which are masses of cytoskeletal elements. It presents with frontal lobe symptoms like personality and behavioural changes. The patient tends to become apathetic and aggressive. There is relative preservation of other cognitive functions like memory.

Other options:

Option A: Lewy body dementia is characterised by visual hallucinations, fluctuating levels of attention and alertness and Parkinsonian features.

Option B: Parkinson's disease is characterised by bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity and resting tremor. It is also commonly associated with dementia and depression.

Option D: Delirium, also known as intensive care unit psychosis, presents with impairment of consciousness with impairment of other cognitive functions like memory, language, orientation and perception.

questions.text: 81. Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) is used in order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU. Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act on?
questions.solution:
The restriction enzyme is likely to act on 5'-GATATC-3'.

Restriction endonuclease(RE) enzymes usually act at specific palindromic sequences which create DNA fragments of different lengths. A palindromic sequence is one that reads the same in opposite directions. By analyzing the fragments produced after cutting the DNA by RE, specific species of bacteria can be identified. Option B, when expanded after writing the complementary sequence, appears the same while reading both DNA strands in the 5' to 3' direction and is hence a palindrome.

5' --GATATC-- 3' 3' --CTATAG-- 5' 

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that recognize and cleave a specific double-stranded DNA sequence. These DNA cuts result in sticky ends or blunt ends. Sticky ends are then used to build hybrid DNA. 

A Restriction fragment length poly­morphism (RFLP) is a genetic variant that can be studied by cleaving the DNA into fragments known as restriction fragments. This is done using a restriction enzyme. The length of the restriction fragments changes if the genetic variant alters the DNA and creates or abolishes the site of restriction endonuclease cleavage. RFLPs can thus be used to find the variation in different staphylococci species.

Other options: 

Options A, C and D: The sequences are not palindromes, as they do not read the same forwards and backwards after expanding. So they cannot be recognized by Restriction endonuclease enzymes.

questions.text: 82. A modified Allen’s test identified grossly inadequate collateral arterial supply to the hand when the radial artery was occluded. Which of the following structures arises primarily from the blocked artery?
questions.solution:
The structure that usually arises from the blocked collateral artery, which is the Ulnar artery is the Superficial Palmar Arch.

The Radial and Ulnar arteries together form the preliminary blood supply to the hand. Both arteries anastomose with each other in the hand, mainly via the superficial and deep palmar arches, and thus, inadequate flow in one can be compensated by the other. Here, the deep arch is not the answer, as its main contribution is from the radial artery, not the ulnar artery.

Modified Allen's test is performed before any procedures involving the Radial artery, such as arterial puncture for blood gas analysis, radial artery graft for CABG, before creation of an A-V fistula, etc. to identify the robustness of the collateral supply to the hand from the Ulnar artery. The test procedure is as follows:

* The patient is asked to make a tight fist and then the radial and ulnar arteries are occluded.

* Then, the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released. 

* If the palm remains pale for more than 5-15 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow. Modified Allen's test is negative. If the palm flushes with blood, it implies that the ulnar artery collateral flow is adequate.

Below is a schematic representation of Modified Allen's test:



There are two arches on the palmar aspect of the hand: the superficial and the deep arch. The main contribution for the superficial arch is the Ulnar artery and for the deep arch is the Radial artery. Both arches are completed by the minor contributing artery, which is a branch of the ulnar artery for the deep arch and a branch of the radial artery for the superficial branch.

Branches of the Radial artery are:

* Palmar carpal branch and dorsal carpal branch

* First dorsal metacarpal artery (The second third and fourth dorsal metacarpal arteries are branches of the dorsal carpal arch formed by the joining of the dorsal carpal branches of the ulnar and radial arteries.)

* Princeps Pollicis artery ( for thumb)

* Radialis Indicis artery ( for the radial side of index finger)

* Deep palmar arch(which gives off the palmar metacarpal arteries that anastomose with the palmar digital arteries.)

* Superficial palmar branch (to complete superficial arch)

Branches of the Ulnar artery are: 

* Dorsal cutaneous branch

* Palmar and dorsal carpal branch

* Deep palmar branch (to complete deep arch)

* Superficial palmar arch

The superficial palmar arch gives rise to one proper palmar digital branch(for the ulnar aspect of the little finger) and three common palmar digital arteries, each of which divides into two proper palmar digital arteries that run along the contiguous sides of all four fingers. Each palmar digital artery has dorsal branches, anastomosing with the dorsal digital arteries.  Hence the blood supply of the hand involves two arches on the palmar side and multiple anastomosis, as shown below:

questions.text: 83. During your ward rounds, you observe a child with the abnormality seen in the image below. Which of the following risk factors would you suspect to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The image depicts caudal regression syndrome, which is associated with overt diabetes mellitus in the mother.

This syndrome encompasses a range of structural abnormalities in the caudal region, which includes incomplete development of the lumbar vertebrae and/or sacrum. It occurs more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers (both preconceptionally and early in pregnancy) than in other infants although the exact mechanism is unclear.
