questions.text: 84. In the given image showing lipoprotein electrophoresis in a normal patient, which of the following bands is responsible for reverse cholesterol transport among 1-4?
questions.solution:
In the given image of lipoprotein electrophoresis, band 4 which represents HDL is responsible for reverse cholesterol transport.

The given image shows four bands representing the four major lipoproteins undergoing electrophoresis. The mobility of lipoproteins on electrophoresis is dependent on factors such as density, protein content, and charge of the particles. The four bands and their properties are listed as follows:

BAND PROPERTY

Band 1: Chylomicron

(At origin)

 Least electrophoretic mobility, Largest size, least density, lowest protein: lipid ratio
Band 2: LDL Known as the Beta lipoprotein band, intermediate electrophoretic mobility
Band 3: VLDL Known as the Pre-beta lipoprotein band, intermediate electrophoretic mobility
Band 4: HDL Known as the Alpha lipoprotein band.Maximum electrophoretic mobility, Smallest size, maximum density, highest protein: lipid ratio


Hence as the protein content of the molecule to lipid content( protein: lipid ratio) increases, the electrophoretic mobility increases. The most mobile is HDL and the least mobile is Chylomicron.



Reverse cholesterol transport is the mechanism of transport of cholesterol from the peripheral tissues back to the liver so that it can be removed from the body. It is achieved via HDL, and the steps summarised are as follows:

Nascent discoidal HDL takes up cholesterol from peripheral tissues. This cholesterol is converted by the LCAT enzyme to cholesteryl esters under the influence of Apo-A1. As HDL accumulates more cholesterol it becomes spherical. SR-B1 receptor in the liver mediates cholesteryl ester reuptake from HDL molecules. This cholesterol is removed from the body as bile acids. questions.text: 85. A 35-year-old male with a history of opioid addiction was admitted to a rehab center and is now being discharged on oral naltrexone tablets for relapse prevention. Which test should be checked prior to starting naltrexone?
questions.solution:
Liver function test should be checked prior to starting naltrexone as it causes hepatoxicity.

Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post addicts.

It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid free for 7-10 days and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration). It decreases the euphoria due to opioid blockade thus decreasing dependence. It also reduces craving in alcohol addicts. 

Naltrexone is metabolized to an active metabolite 6β-naltrexone, and eliminated primarily via active renal secretion.

Common side effects include nausea and headache and hepatotoxicity. Thus, contraindicated in patients with frank liver failure and raised AST and ALT more than 3 times the normal value.

questions.text: 87. A 50-year-old woman came with complaints of dull-aching pain in her hips and back. She was diagnosed with bilateral mixed conductive and a sensorineural hearing loss last month. A blood workup revealed normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray of her lower limbs showed flame-shaped osteolytic lesion and cortical thickening. Which of the following is the best among the given treatment options?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Paget's disease of the bone. It is also known as osteitis deformans. The most appropriate treatment for this patient with Paget's disease is IV Zoledronate- a bisphosphonate. 

It is characterized by an increased bone turnover due to a disorganized, alternating, and increased rate of osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. It may be monostotic or polyostotic. 

Clinically, it is seen more commonly in people over the age of 50. A majority of the patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with bone pain, which is constant and dull aching and mostly involves the long bones of the lower limbs, back, and hips. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones, the tibia bending anteriorly and the femur bending anterolaterally.

Skull bones may be enlarged, and the base of the skull may be flattened. Disorganised and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina, resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis, resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. One of the most baleful complications, however, is the increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. 

Other complications include osteoarthritis, high-output cardiac failure, and hypercalcemia. 

Laboratory investigations reveal-

* Normal calcium and phosphate levels

* Increased bone-specific alkaline phosphatase due to increased osteoblastic activity

* Increased serum levels of collagen crosslinked peptides such as CTX (C-telopeptide) due to bone resorption

* Increased urinary markers such as hydroxyproline, deoxypyridinoline, C-telopeptide, and N-telopeptide.

X-ray findings in Paget's disease reveal both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions. Characteristic radiographic findings include-

* Brim sign- Seen in Paget's disease of the pelvis due to a thickened iliopectineal line.

* Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 

* Picture-frame appearance may be seen in vertebral bodies due to enlarged coarse trabeculae surrounded by a prominent radiodense periphery.

* Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.

* Osteoporosis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The aim of the treatment of Paget disease is to limit excessive bone remodelling and to reduce pain. The mainstay of treatment is therefore bisphosphonates as they inhibit osteoclastic activity, limiting bone resorption and disease progression. IV zoledronate is the preferred bisphosphonate. It is administered as a single IV dose of 4-5 mg and has the most sustained response. It is, however, contraindicated in renal insufficiency. 

Therapeutic uses of bisphosphonates- 

* Osteoporosis including postmenopausal and steroid-induced

* Paget disease 

* Tumor-associated osteolysis 

* Hypercalcemia.

questions.text: 88. Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Globular (G) actin is a part of microfilaments and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibres are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).


3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing centre (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: 90. Inhibition of antagonistic muscle groups occurs by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of inhibition of antagonistic muscle is via reciprocal inhibition.

Afferent fibers from muscle spindles are related to the spinal motor neuron complex that supplies the same muscle. When an impulse is generated, an excitatory potential is generated that leads to the action in the muscle. Meanwhile, an inhibitory potential is produced in the motor neurons supplying the antagonistic muscle group. By this mechanism, there is both an excitatory and an inhibitory impulse known as reciprocal inhibition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Lateral inhibition: Stimulation of one motor neuron inhibits adjacent motor neurons. This is known as lateral inhibition. Signals from the spinal motor neurons stimulate Renshaw cells, which are inhibitory interneurons. Renshaw cells transmit inhibitory signals to the adjacent motor neurons, by releasing the neurotransmitter glycine. This helps in sharpening signals in order to maintain the desired direction of signal transmission. 

Option C: Feedback inhibition (Recurrent inhibition): Signals from neurons may inhibit themselves by negative feedback. This is known as feedback inhibition or recurrent inhibition. Signals from a neuron may stimulate the Renshaw cell, which in turn inhibits the same neuron.

Option D: Feedforward inhibition: Signals from neurons stimulate inhibitory cells. These inhibitory cells then inhibit a different group of neurons. This is called feedforward inhibition. For example, granule cells stimulate the inhibitory basket cells and stellate cells via parallel fibers. These basket and stellate cells then inhibit the Purkinje cells. This is known as feedforward inhibition.

questions.text: 91. The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves in hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, respectively, shift to
questions.solution:
In cases of hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right and left, respectively.

In carbon monoxide poisoning, the affinity of Hb for CO is about 200 times more than that for O2, and hence, the COHb releases the CO into the blood very slowly. The O2–Hb dissociation curve of the remaining hemoglobin shifts to the left.



Graph of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve in anemia was tested recently in INICET May 2023. In chronic anemia, there is marked hemoglobin deficiency associated with increased 2-3, DPG in red blood cells, and as a result, the O2- Hb dissociation curve shifts to the right.

PSVT- Paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Intravenous adenosine is preferred for termination of arrhythmia in this patient who is stable with regular and narrow complex PSVT (paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia).

Carotid sinus massage is provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke as in this patient (Option A).

Adenosine may precipitate atrial fibrillation.

IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (Dilitazem) are typically used for PSVT  after adenosine fails (Option C)

IV Procainamide (Option D) is used if the above agents fail to terminate the arrhythmia.

questions.text: 93. An epidemiologist is calculating the incubation period for measles in children aged 2 to 14 years. He was assigned a rural area with a sizeable portion of unvaccinated children and adolescents. He takes the sample size as 100. The median incubation period is 10 days. Given that the standard error is 0.4 what is the standard deviation in this case?
questions.solution:
The standard deviation in this case 4.

From the formula for standard error (SE) = Standard deviation/ square root of sample size,

Standard deviation (SD) = (Standard error) x (square root of sample size)                                           = 0.4 x √100                                     SD = 0.4 x 10 = 4

Pearl PM1089: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

* Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.

* Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):

* This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.

* Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.

For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.

* Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:

* The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)

* Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape

* Assuming all samples are identical in size

* The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 

* Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):

* The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

* Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 

* More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 

SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: 94. In a 48-year-old patient with type-2 diabetes mellitus, fundus examination revealed the presence of hard exudates. In which of the below-marked layers of the retina would you appreciate this finding?
questions.solution:
Hard exudates mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer - layer 3. It can be identified as it lies between two nuclear layers. 

In the given image:

* Inner plexiform layer

* Inner nuclear layer

* Outer plexiform layer

* Outer nuclear layer

Hard exudates are the extravasation of fluid rich in fibrin and protein around the area of leaking micro-aneurysms. They mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer. They appear as well-defined small, bright yellow deposits with crenated margins.





Common eye findings seen in retinal vascular diseases and the layers involved:

Microaneurysms are seen as a result of focal dilation of the capillary wall following loss of pericytes. They are commonly observed in the inner nuclear layer. 

Soft exudates, also known as ‘cotton wool spots’, occur due to the accumulation of cellular debris that occurs as a result of ischemia. They are seen in the nerve fiber layer. They appear as ill-defined, cloud-like soft aggregates with feathery margins.

Flame hemorrhages are due to the rupture of blood vessels in the nerve fiber layer. They assume flame shape because of the collection of blood in between the parallel running nerve fibers.

Drusen are extracellular deposits seen in age-related macular degeneration. These are located in the interface between the retinal pigmentary epithelium and Bruch membrane.

questions.text: 95. Which of the following placental hormones is mainly responsible for decreasing maternal insulin sensitivity and increasing lipolysis to ensure adequate glucose supply for the fetus?
questions.solution:
Human placental lactogen (hPL) is mainly responsible for decreasing maternal insulin sensitivity and increasing lipolysis to ensure adequate glucose supply for the fetus.

hPL is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast and promotes insulin resistance, reducing maternal glucose uptake. It increases lipolysis, ensuring adequate free fatty acids for maternal energy while preserving glucose for the fetus. It plays a key role in the pathophysiology of gestational diabetes too.

Other options:

Option A: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): hCG supports the corpus luteum, ensuring progesterone production in early pregnancy. It does not play a role in insulin resistance or lipolysis.

Option C: Placental Growth Hormone (PGH): Placental growth hormone also affects maternal metabolism, but hPL is the primary hormone responsible for insulin resistance and lipolysis. PGH mainly stimulates IGF-1, promoting fetal growth.

Option D: Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH): CRH is involved in labor initiation by stimulating fetal ACTH and increasing fetal cortisol and DHEA-S. It does not directly impact maternal insulin resistance.

questions.text: 96. Which of the following veins accompanies the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the left anterior descending artery located in the anterior interventricular groove. The vein which accompanies this artery is the great cardiac vein. 

The great cardiac vein begins at the apex of the heart. It ascends in the anterior interventricular sulcus. At the coronary sulcus, the great cardiac vein turns to the left and lies at the base of the heart. Here, it is associated with the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. In the coronary sulcus, the great cardiac vein enlarges to form the coronary sinus, which drains into the right atrium.





Middle cardiac vein begins near the apex of the heart and ascends in the posterior interventricular sulcus. It is associated with the posterior interventricular branch of the right or the left coronary artery. Small cardiac vein begins in the anterior section of the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. It continues in this groove onto the base of the heart and then enters the coronary sinus. It accompanies the right coronary artery in its course and may receive the right marginal vein. Posterior cardiac vein lies on the posterior surface of the left ventricle just to the left of the middle cardiac vein. 

Anterior veins of the right ventricle drain the anterior portion of the right ventricle and enter the right atrium directly. Venae cordis minimae or veins of Thebasius drain directly into the cardiac chambers and are mainly associated with right atrium and right ventricle.

questions.text: 97. A 45-year-old woman has a painless thyroid nodule found on a routine exam. FNAC reveals orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies. Which genetic alteration is most common in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a thyroid nodule with FNAC showing orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies has papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). The most common genetic alteration in PTC is the BRAF V600E mutation.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy arising from thyroid follicular cells. Risk factors include radiation exposure, family history, and certain genetic syndromes. It typically spreads via lymphatics, leading to cervical lymph node metastases. PTC generally has an excellent prognosis.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is strongly associated with the BRAF V600E mutation. This mutation leads to constitutive activation of the MAPK signaling pathway, promoting uncontrolled cell proliferation and tumor growth.

Other conditions associated with BRAF V600E mutations:

* Melanoma

* Hairy Cell Leukemia

* Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer 

* Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis

* Colon adenocarcinoma

Option C: RAS mutations are more commonly seen in Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC) and follicular variants of PTC rather than classic PTC.

Option D: PAX8-PPARγ translocation is a defining feature of Follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC), not papillary carcinoma.

questions.text: 98. A 58-year-old male presents with progressive nephrotic syndrome, macroglossia, and restrictive cardiomyopathy. A renal biopsy is performed, and histopathology reveals extracellular eosinophilic deposits that show apple-green birefringence under polarized light with Congo red staining. Which of the following is the primary protein involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of nephrotic syndrome, macroglossia, and restrictive cardiomyopathy is highly suggestive of primary (AL) amyloidosis, which is caused by the deposition of immunoglobulin light chains.

In AL amyloidosis, monoclonal plasma cells overproduce light chains, which misfold and form amyloid fibrils that deposit in various organs. The kidney involvement leads to nephrotic syndrome, while amyloid deposits in the heart cause restrictive cardiomyopathy with diastolic dysfunction. Macroglossia is a hallmark finding, as amyloid accumulation in the tongue causes enlargement and firmness, often leading to speech and swallowing difficulties.

The characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light with Congo red staining confirms the presence of amyloid fibrils. Evaluation with serum and urine protein electrophoresis (SPEP/UPEP) and free light chain assays is done to confirm clonal plasma cell proliferation. Treatment often includes chemotherapy with proteasome inhibitors (e.g., bortezomib) and autologous stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Beta-2 microglobulin is associated with dialysis-related amyloidosis.

Option B: Transthyretin is involved in hereditary or age-related ATTR amyloidosis.

Option C: Amyloid A protein is responsible for secondary (AA) amyloidosis, which occurs in chronic inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: 99. Which of the following anterior pituitary hormones share a common Alpha(α) subunit that is the product of a single gene?
questions.solution:
FSH, LH, and TSH hormones of anterior pituitary share a common Alpha(α) subunit.

Five types of secretory cells have been identified in the anterior pituitary. They are

* Somatotropes: which secrete growth hormone

* Lactotropes (also called mammotropes): which secrete prolactin

* Corticotropes: which secrete ACTH

* Thyrotropes: which secrete TSH

* Gonadotropes: which secrete FSH and LH.

It is notable that the three pituitary glycoprotein hormones i.e FSH, LH, and TSH while being made up of two subunits, all share a common α subunit that is the product of a single gene and has the same amino acid composition in each hormone, although their carbohydrate residues vary. 

The α subunit must be combined with the β subunit characteristic of each hormone for maximal physiologic activity.

questions.text: 100. A new disease-modifying drug X is being developed for the management of rheumatoid arthritis. A randomized controlled trial is being conducted among 1000 patients to compare the efficacy of drug X to methotrexate. Identify the phase of the clinical trial.
questions.solution:
The given scenario where a randomized controlled trial is being conducted among 1000 patients with rheumatoid arthritis to compare the efficacy of a new disease-modifying drug X with methotrexate (i.e. the existing standard of care) is indicative of phase 3 of a clinical trial. 

Clinical trials are experimental studies involving humans that compare the therapeutic benefits of 2 or more treatment options, or of a particular treatment to a placebo. They are divided into the following phases:

* Phase 0 - This is a new strategy being developed to reduce the cost and time of the drug development process. It involves a micro-dosing study undertaken before the phase 1 trial for initial pharmacokinetic assessment. Very low doses, generally about 1/100th of the estimated human dose, are administered to healthy volunteers and pharmacokinetics is worked out. 

* Phase 1 (Option A) - A phase where subjects (mostly about 10-100 healthy volunteers) are exposed to the lowest possible dose, increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose. The emphasis is to work out the safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous side effects.

* Phase 2 (Option B) - This phase involves about 100-500 patients with the disease and is used to work out the therapeutic efficacy, optimal dosing strategy, and ceiling effect of the drug in a controlled setting. 

* Phase 3 - This phase involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug X in the question) or to the present standard of care (e.g., methotrexate as the first-line disease-modifying antirheumatic drug). The aim is to establish the value of the drug in relation to existing therapy. If it is better than existing modalities, indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated.

* Phase 4 (Option D) - This is a phase of postmarketing surveillance of patients after the treatment is approved. It is used to detect efficacy, rare or long-term adverse effects, and evaluate cost-effectiveness.

questions.text: 101. According to the Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA), what colour sticker will be placed on the Mother and Child Protection (MCP) Card of a primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation, who presents with pedal edema and a blood pressure value of 150/100 mmHg?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a primigravida presenting with elevated blood pressure ( SBP ≥ 140 mmHg and DBP ≥ 90 mmHg ) along with pedal edema is suggestive of pregnancy-induced hypertension and a blue sticker will be placed on this patient's MCP card according to the PMSMA.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month. This is undertaken as part of the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child Plus Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy.

Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

* Green- For women with no detected risk factor

* Red- For women with detected risk factor

* Blue- for women with pregnancy-induced hypertension

* Yellow- pregnancy with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes, hypothyroidism, STIs

questions.text: 102. A 39-year-old morbidly-obese female patient presented with deranged liver function test. Ultrasound showed a grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, and has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is considered the first-line treatment for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

* Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.

* Dose: 800 IU/day.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Most of the patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work. Some patients with NASH can present with right upper quadrant pain due to stretching of the liver capsule from hepatomegaly, or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance or with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis. Currently, a biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia). Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Other options:

Option A- Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C- Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

Option D- N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: 103. A 34-year-old male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumour (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.



The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.



Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumours, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumour cells in a space that is also lined by tumour cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers- islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of the thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

questions.text: 104. A 20-year-old male patient was diagnosed to be a case of colorectal cancer. On further evaluation, he was found to have desmoid tumours, epidermoid cysts and osteoma of the mandible. Genetic studies revealed APC gene mutation. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and APC gene mutation are suggestive of Gardner's syndrome (a variant of Familial adenomatous polyposis).

Gardner's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) caused by an abnormal APC gene on Chromosome 5. 

Components

* Colorectal polyps

* Osteomas of the jaw or skull

* Epidermoid cysts

* Soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is defined clinically by the presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterised by duodenal adenomas and multiple extraintestinal manifestations. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. 

The aim of surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).

The other surgical options include:

* Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)

* Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC)

* Total proctectomy and end ileostomy

Other Options:

Option A: If a brain tumor arises in a patient with either HNPCC or FAP, then the patient is considered to have Turcot syndrome.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)/ Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in one of the DNA mismatch repair genes. The most commonly affected genes are MLH1 and MSH2. It is characterised by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and also cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine. 

Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by hyperpigmentation of the mouth and lips, and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines.

Pearl PM1259: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

* Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100

* Gastric and duodenal polyps are present

* Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma

* Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.

* Epidermoid cysts

* Desmoid tumors in the abdomen

* Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia

* Brain tumors

* Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: 105. A 55-year-old male with liver cirrhosis presents with worsening ascites, reduced urine output, and elevated serum creatinine (2.5 mg/dL). USG shows a normal kidney. His medications include spironolactone, furosemide, propranolol, lactulose, and rifaximin. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Stop diuretics and initiate albumin infusion
Increase the dose of diuretics and add albumin infusion

questions.solution:
A 55-year-old male with liver cirrhosis with worsening ascites, reduced urine output, and elevated serum creatinine (2.5 mg/dL) suggests a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome and the next best step would be to stop diuretics and start albumin infusion as diuretics decrease circulatory volume causing renal hypoperfusion.

Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a functional renal failure seen in around 10% of patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure, without underlying kidney disease. It involves disturbances in renal circulation, such as increased renal vascular resistance and decreased systemic vascular resistance, splanchnic vasodilation with renal hypoperfusion.

Type 1 HRS is characterized by rapid deterioration of renal function over 1–2 weeks, while Type 2 HRS presents with stable but reduced renal function, with a better prognosis than Type 1. 

Diagnostic criteria:

* Progressive rise in serum creatinine in patients with ascites.

* Absence of intrinsic kidney disease (normal renal ultrasound and no proteinuria or hematuria).

* No evidence of shock or ongoing infection.

* No current or recent use of nephrotoxic drugs, including NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, or iodinated contrast agents.

* No improvement in renal function after 2 days of diuretic withdrawal and administration of albumin (1 g/kg/day).

Treatment initially includes diuretic withdrawal with albumin infusion followed by usage of vasoconstrictors like terlipressin, norepinephrine (with ICU monitoring), or midodrine with octreotide and albumin. The best long-term treatment is liver transplantation, which often restores renal function. Without transplantation, the prognosis is poor.

questions.text: 106. Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction in pulmonary circulation results due to inhibition of which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction in pulmonary circulation results due to the inhibition of the potassium channel.

Hypoxia induces vasoconstriction by inhibition of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cell membranes. This leads to depolarization of the cell membrane and activation of calcium channels causing the influx of calcium ions. The rise of calcium concentration then causes constriction of small arteries and arterioles.

When the concentration of O2 in the alveoli decreases below normal the adjacent blood vessels constrict. This effect is opposite to the effect observed in systemic vessels, which dilate rather than constrict in response to low O2 levels.

This is because the low oxygen concentrations can

* Stimulate the release of or increase sensitivity to vasoconstrictor substances such as endothelin or reactive oxygen species.

* Decrease the release of vasodilators such as nitric oxide from the lung.

questions.text: 107. Which of the following statements is correct about the image?
questions.solution:
1 has mean>median>mode.

1 represents positively skewed data as the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box.

* For positively skewed data, mean > median > mode.

2 represents negatively skewed data as the median is closer to the top of the box, and the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box.

* For negatively skewed data, mean < median < mode.





A box and whisker plot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. The lines extending vertically from the boxes are known as whiskers and indicate variability outside the upper and lower quartiles.



Pearl PM0972: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

* The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.

* In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.

* Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.

* Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.



Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode


* As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.

* A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.



* Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as: Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).

* Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.

* In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.

* Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text:
108. A 38-year-old male patient diagnosed with malaria was commenced on an anti-malarial drug. After two days, port wine-colored urine was noted. His lab reports are given below. What is your diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9.0 g/dL Blood glucose - 100 mg/dL Serum creatinine - 5.6 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with malaria treated with an anti-malarial drug (likely quinine) developing hemoglobinuria (port-wine stained urine), hemolysis (reduced hemoglobin), and renal failure (increased creatinine) is suggestive of blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever (malarial hemoglobinuria) is an autoimmune process seen in Falciparum malaria, particularly in patients who have experienced repeated past infections and inadequate treatment with quinine. Clinical manifestations include fever, prostration, hemoglobinuria, and bilious vomiting, with the passage of dark red or blackish urine. 

It is due to massive intravascular hemolysis caused by anti-erythrocyte antibodies, leading to massive absorption of hemoglobin by the renal tubules (hemoglobinuric nephrosis), producing blackwater fever. Complications of blackwater fever include renal failure, acute liver failure, and circulatory collapse. 

Complications of Falciparum malaria include:

* Cerebral malaria

* Algid malaria

* Septicemic malaria

* Blackwater fever

* Pulmonary edema

* Acute renal failure

* Hypoglycemia (glucose <40 mg/dL)

* Severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL, PCV <15%)

* Metabolic acidosis

* Shock

* Bleeding disturbances

Other options:

Option A: Septicemic malaria is characterized by high continuous fever with the dissemination of the parasite to various organs, leading to multiorgan failure.

Option B: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D: Cerebral malaria is manifested by features of diffuse symmetric encephalopathy like headache, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, slowly lapsing into a coma.

questions.text: 109. A 13-year-old child who weighs 60 kg weight and is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 13 year old obese child with hypothyroidism with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip and tenderness in Scarpa's triangle points towards a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

* Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.

* On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.

* There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.

* Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.

* Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

* Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.



Other options-

Option A: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Option C: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option D: Fracture neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors).

questions.text: 110. A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency after a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically stable and complains of flank pain. eFAST is positive. A CECT was performed, which revealed grade 3 splenic trauma, and there is no contrast blush. What is the next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is hemodynamically stable and has a grade 3 splenic laceration without associated intraperitoneal injuries; the best approach is non-operative management, including bed rest and serial hematocrit monitoring.

The American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale classifies splenic injuries from Grades 1 to 5 based on hematoma size, laceration depth, and vascular involvement:

* Grade 1: Subcapsular hematoma <10% of surface area or laceration <1 cm deep.

* Grade 2: Subcapsular hematoma 10–50%, intraparenchymal hematoma <5 cm, or laceration 1–3 cm deep.

* Grade 3: Subcapsular hematoma >50%, intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm, or laceration >3 cm deep.

* Grade 4: Segmental or hilar vascular injury with major devascularization (>25% of the spleen).

* Grade 5: Shattered spleen or complete hilar devascularization.

Grades 1-3 are usually managed conservatively if stable, while Grades 4-5 often require intervention.

Grade 3

Same management as grades 4 and 5

Other options:

Option A: Exploratory laparotomy is not indicated in a stable patient without signs of peritonitis or ongoing bleeding.

Option C: Angioembolization is done for patients with a contrast blush (active bleeding) or higher-grade injuries.

Option D: Exploratory laparotomy and splenectomy is considered when there is hemodynamic instability or irreparable splenic damage

questions.text: 111. A newborn with persistent umbilical stump bleeding, easy bruising, and delayed wound healing has normal PT, aPTT, thrombin time, and platelet count. The urea clot solubility test is positive. What is the primary defect?

choices.text: Deficiency of a transglutaminase enzyme required for fibrin cross-linking
Impaired activation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
Defective cleavage of von Willebrand factor
Defective platelet adhesion due to GpIb deficiency

questions.solution:
This newborn presents with persistent umbilical stump bleeding, easy bruising, and delayed wound healing despite normal PT, aPTT, thrombin time, and platelet count. These findings suggest Factor XIII deficiency, a rare transglutaminase enzyme deficiency that prevents proper fibrin cross-linking.

Factor XIII deficiency is a rare coagulation disorder characterized by impaired fibrin cross-linking, which leads to unstable clots that break down prematurely. Factor XIII is a transglutaminase enzyme that stabilizes fibrin by forming covalent bonds between fibrin monomers. Its deficiency results in delayed bleeding, which often presents as persistent umbilical stump bleeding, easy bruising, and poor wound healing despite normal PT, aPTT, thrombin time, and platelet count. 

Other options:

Option B: Impaired activation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors is seen in vitamin K deficiency, which affects factors II, VII, IX, and X, leading to prolonged PT and aPTT, unlike this patient’s normal coagulation tests.

Option C: Defective cleavage of von Willebrand factor is characteristic of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) due to ADAMTS13 deficiency, which causes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia.

Option D: Defective platelet adhesion due to GpIb deficiency is seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome, which presents with thrombocytopenia and giant platelets, unlike this case, which has normal platelet count and function.

questions.text:
113. A 52-year-old woman presents with generalized fatigue, mild bone pain, and a history of recurrent kidney stones. Her lab reports are given below. A sestamibi scan identifies a single enlarged parathyroid gland. There is no evidence of ectopic gland or distant metastasis. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management?

Serum calcium - 12.3 mg/dL (Normal : 8.5–10.5 mg/dL) intact PTH - Elevated  Alkaline phosphatase - Mildly elevated
questions.solution:
The patient has elevated serum calcium and intact PTH (biologically active PTH) and an enlarged parathyroid gland, which suggests primary hyperparathyroidism due to a single parathyroid adenoma. This condition is best managed with focused parathyroidectomy, which targets only the affected gland while preserving normal parathyroid tissue. 

Parathyroid adenomas lead to hypercalcemia with symptoms such as nephrolithiasis, osteoporosis, fatigue, depression, muscle weakness, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum calcium and inappropriately high PTH levels.  Imaging for localization includes sestamibi scintigraphy and neck ultrasound, which help identify the adenoma’s location. Four-dimensional CT (4D-CT) or MRI may be used. Bone mineral density (BMD) testing via DEXA scan is essential to assess skeletal impact.

Surgical removal (focussed parathyroidectomy) is the definitive treatment for symptomatic patients and those meeting the criteria for surgery (e.g., osteoporosis, nephrolithiasis, significant hypercalcemia). Intraoperative PTH monitoring ensures complete removal. Non-surgical management with hydration, bisphosphonates, and cinacalcet is reserved for patients who are poor surgical candidates. 

Parathyroid carcinoma is typically a more aggressive and symptomatic disease than parathyroid adenoma. Patients often present with more pronounced clinical features, including severe hypercalcemia (typically >14 mg/dL), markedly elevated PTH levels (often 3–10 times the upper limit of normal), and elevated alkaline phosphatase. Symptoms may include palpable neck masses, hoarseness or vocal cord palsy. The definitive diagnosis is on the basis of invasion and metastasis, and is usually post-operative. 

Other options:

Option A: Surgery is the definitive treatment for symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism. Medical management (hydration, bisphosphonates, cinacalcet) is reserved for poor surgical candidates or mild asymptomatic cases.

Option B: Subtotal parathyroidectomy is used for parathyroid hyperplasia which typically involves all four parathyroid glands. 

Option D: En-bloc resection is reserved for parathyroid carcinoma, not adenoma.

questions.text: 114. A patient underwent Modified Duke’s Staging for an exophytic ulcerated growth eight centimeters from the anal verge and was found to have Stage C1 disease. Which of the following treatment strategies is least relevant in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
In Modified Duke Stage C1 rectal carcinoma 8 cm from the anal verge, abdominoperineal resection is the least relevant treatment strategy among the given options.

The given clinical scenario describes an exophytic ulcerative lesion 8 cm from the anal verge being staged using the Duke Staging system. This case of rectal malignancy has 3 salient findings useful for deciding treatment options:

*  The lesion is 8cm from the anal verge- can do sphincter preserving operation (Option A)

* The lesion is Modified Duke Stage C1- must do total mesorectal excision (Option C)

* Duke C1 lesions will be local lymph node-positive- must give chemotherapy post-operation (Option D)

Abdominoperineal resection is usually attempted when the lesion is in the distal rectum, less than 5 centimeters from the anal verge, and obtaining clear margins is only possible by sacrificing the sphincter. Here, the lesion is in the mid-rectum.

In all cases of rectal carcinoma, an attempt must be made to conserve the sphincter function of the individual wherever possible by adopting sphincter-preserving approaches to surgery such as Low Anterior Resection, which is preferred here. In LAR, the rectum and mesorectum surrounding the lesion are removed, preserving the sphincters, and the colon and rectal stump are stapled together.

In Abdominoperineal resection(APR), which changes the normal anatomy of defecation completely, the rectum is approached and excised from the abdomen and the perineum simultaneously, and the colon is brought out as a permanent colostomy after permanent closure of the perineum.

Duke's staging of rectal cancer is given below:

DUKE STAGE FINDING
A Lesion confined to the bowel wall
B Lesion penetrates muscularis propria, and involves extra rectal tissue but not lymph nodes
C1 Local Pararectal node involvement
C2 Apical node( along blood vessels) involvement
D Distant metastasis( often to the liver)


In this patient, stage C1 disease implies lymph node involvement. In all cases with positive lymph nodes, it is necessary to do a total mesorectal excision(TME) of Heald and give postoperative chemotherapy. TME is a surgical procedure where the mesorectum surrounding the rectum that contains lymphatic structures in continuity with the rectum is completely excised and removed.

Chemotherapy is indicated in two ways: as neoadjuvant and adjuvant. Neoadjuvant therapy along with radiation downstages the tumor before surgery. A  wait-and-watch approach with neoadjuvant chemoradiation is known to even resolve some lesions. Adjuvant therapy after surgery is done to reduce recurrence and ensure a complete cure. 

The regimens used are usually either the FOLFOX regimen containing Folinic Acid, 5- Fluorouracil, and Oxaliplatin or a CAPOX/ Xelox regimen containing Capecitabine and Oxaliplatin. Chemotherapy is given in all Stage 3,4 and lymph node-positive cancers.

questions.text: 115. Which of the following scenarios is not included under cognizable offense?

choices.text: Accepting gift hampers on referral of patient
Operating under the influence of alcohol

questions.solution:
Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients is not a cognizable offense. 

Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients comes under dichotomy. It is a type of unethical act, wherein a physician offers or receives any gift or bonus for referring or procuring any patient for medical or surgical treatment. 

A cognizable offense is that in which a police officer can arrest a person without having a warrant from the magistrate. Examples include cases of rape, murder, dowry death, and death due to rash or negligent acts. In such cases, the individual is sent by the police to the doctor for a medical examination. 

Punishments for cognizable offense: 

* Death

* Imprisonment for life

* Imprisonment could be rigorous and involve hard labor

* Forfeiture of property

* Fine

In non-cognizable offenses, the accused cannot be arrested without a warrant issued by the magistrate. The injured person can directly go to the doctor or he may file an affidavit in the court of a magistrate, who will send him to the doctor for examination and report. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Operating under the influence of alcohol and performing amputation on the wrong limb come under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence is when a doctor lacks gross skill or care while treating, which results in serious injury/death of the patient, or when an illegal act is performed by a doctor. Criminal negligence is a cognizable offense.

Option D: Ragging in any form is a cognizable offense.

Pearl PM2391: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

* Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.

* Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions

* Refuses to take the treatment

* Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice

* Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

* Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.

* Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

* Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text:
116. Which of the following are true regarding vitamin D synthesis?

* Synthesis occurs sequentially in the skin, liver, kidney

* Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin

* 25 hydroxylase acts in the kidney

* 1-α-hydroxylase is present in the liver
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1 and 2.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin. 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis:

Step 1: In the skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Step 2: In the liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol). The enzyme responsible for this is 25 hydroxylase. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3: In the kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to either 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

The synthesis of vitamin D is summarized in the image below.

Pearl PM1613: Important Clinical Features of Rickets



Pearl PM1959: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

* Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 

* Delayed appearance of the epiphysis

* Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.

* Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.

* Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

* Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices

* In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

* Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia

* Wrist: especially the ulna

* Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: 117. A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition that occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin, having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

* Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart or,

* Presence of bipedal oedema or,

* Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115 mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below).



The children should be assessed for the following: 

* Severe edema 

* Low appetite (failed appetite test) 

* Medical complications 

* One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing haemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting oedema starting in the legs and feet and spreading to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the oedema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.



Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

questions.text: 118. A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive leg swelling, aching pain, and visible dilated veins that worsen after prolonged standing. Examination reveals hyperpigmentation and pitting edema in the lower legs. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of her condition?

choices.text: Failure of the calf muscle pump

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of leg swelling, dilated veins with hyperpigmentation, and pitting edema suggest varicose veins. The pathophysiology for the same is failure of the calf muscle pump, leading to venous hypertension.

Varicose veins result from chronic venous hypertension due to incompetent valves in the superficial veins. When the calf muscles contract, they normally propel blood upward, but with dysfunctional valves, blood refluxes, leading to pooling and progressive vein dilation. Over time, venous wall damage worsens, causing increased pressure, venous stasis, and secondary skin changes like hyperpigmentation and ulceration.

Clinically, varicose veins present with leg swelling, aching pain, visible tortuous veins, and skin changes. Management includes compression therapy, lifestyle modifications (e.g., leg elevation, walking), and sclerotherapy or venous ablation procedures.

Other options:

Option B: Obstruction of deep veins occurs in deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which presents with acute pain and asymmetric swelling, not chronic skin changes.

Option C: Increased arterial pressure affects arteries rather than veins and does not cause venous hypertension.

Option D: Lymphatic dysfunction leads to non-pitting edema, unlike the pitting edema seen in venous disease.

questions.text: 119. The following image depicts the dissection of the forearm. Identify structure marked by the red arrow.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the pronator quadratus muscle.

Pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. The muscle is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery and causes the pronation of the forearm.

questions.text: 120. Which of the following characteristics distinguishes necroptosis from apoptosis?

choices.text: Loss of ATP and swelling of organelles
Induction by ligation of Fas receptors

questions.solution:
Loss of ATP and swelling of organelles are present in necroptosis, and not apoptosis. 

Morphologically, necroptosis resembles necrosis, characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), release of lysosomal enzymes, and eventual plasma membrane rupture. In contrast, apoptosis involves cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, with the plasma membrane remaining intact until these bodies are phagocytosed.

Receptor-mediated initiation (Option A) is a feature common to both apoptosis and necroptosis. Apoptosis can be initiated by death receptor ligation, such as Fas or TNFR1, and necroptosis is similarly initiated by receptor ligation. Therefore, Fas ligation can trigger both processes (Option D).

The initiation of necroptosis, like apoptosis, involves signal transduction pathways that culminate in cell death (Option C).

Feature Apoptosis Necroptosis
Induction stimuli Oxidative stress, death receptor ligands, and chemotherapy Viral or chemical exposure, radiation, endogenous or pathological factors
Morphological changes   Nuclear pyknosis, membrane blebbing, generation of apoptotic bodies Cellular and organelle enlargement accompanied by disruption of membrane integrity
Molecular changes Cleavage of caspases, DNA fragmentation Acidosis, random DNA degradation, and release of cellular proteins
Clearance Apoptotic bodies are cleared through phagocytosis by adjacent cells or resident macrophages Necrotic cells ingested by macrophages, significant inflammation

questions.text: 121. Which subtype of breast carcinoma among the following shows a loss of E-cadherin expression?
questions.solution:
Lobular carcinoma subtype of breast carcinoma shows a loss of E-cadherin expression.

Lobular carcinoma of the breast is characterized by biallelic loss of expression of CDH1, the gene responsible for encoding E-cadherin. These carcinomas display dyscohesive behavior, infiltrating as individual cells. Additionally, their tendency to sometimes lack a desmoplastic response makes it difficult to detect them clinically. 

E-cadherin is a transmembrane protein essential for maintaining cohesion among normal epithelial cells in the breast and other glandular tissues. It acts as a tumor suppressor protein and is lost in cases of lobular carcinoma.

In lobular carcinoma of the breast, the histopathological examination shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern.

The image below shows the single file pattern seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast:



Other options:

Option B: Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with mutations and reduced expression of BRCA1. 

Option C: Inflammatory carcinoma is a diffusely infiltrative carcinoma caused by the extensive invasion of the lymphovascular space. It carries a poor prognosis. It presents with breast erythema, swelling, and skin thickening. It is unlikely to be associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression.

Option D: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a neoplastic proliferation of epithelial cells limited by the basement membrane. It involves the ducts and lobules. It is not associated with a loss of E-cadherin expression.

questions.text: 122. A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of loss of libido and weakness. Physical examination revealed coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands. MRI showed a pituitary mass. Which of the following screening tests would you order to diagnose the cause of the mass?
questions.solution:
The screening test to diagnose the cause of the mass would be serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels.

The clinical features (loss of libido, weakness, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands) are suggestive of acromegaly caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumour. However, since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

* Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours

* Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours

* Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Other options:

24-hour urinary-free cortisol and ACTH levels are useful in screening for Cushing's disease.

Pearl PM1525: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: 123. Which of the following does this dose-response curve represent?
questions.solution:
The given dose-response curve represents potentiation. 

Potentiation is a type of allosteric effect that occurs when an allosteric ligand binds to a different site on the receptor and potentiates the response. This is indicated by the left shift in the dose-response curve. This allosteric effect is saturable and potentiation reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.



Other options:

Option B: In non-competitive antagonism, there is a flattening of the agonist dose-response curve. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor (allosteric site) and inhibit the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied as depicted below.



Option C: In competitive antagonism, the dose-response curve shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist, as shown below.



Option D: In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text:
124. A 48-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to diarrhea since 3 days. Laboratory values are as follows. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH = 7.2

PCO2 = 30 mmHg

HCO3 = 7 mEq/L

Cl = 120 mEq/L

Na = 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with an  increased anion gap

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate (HCO3) level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28 mEq/L) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence, this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- [(Cl-)+(HCO3-)]

= 135-(120+7)

= 8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence anion gap is within the normal range.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.
