If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text:
125. A 8-year-old child presented with the deformity shown in the image. Subsequent investigations revealed a mutation in the PHEX gene and increased levels of fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF 23). Which of the following blood parameters is most likely to be seen in this patient ?

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
Low serum PO4  is the likely blood parameter seen in this patient.

The given clinical scenario with the image showing the wind-swept deformity (characteristic of rickets in a pediatric patient) and PHEX gene mutation is suggestive of a diagnosis of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets. 

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets. But the overall most common cause of rickets remains to be nutritional vitamin D deficiency. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on X chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels. This leads to impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate and hence the excretion of phosphorous is increased. It also inhibits renal 1-alpha hydroxylase leading to reduced 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D. 

The patient's laboratory reports will show low phosphate levels or increased urinary phosphate. All other parameters such as calcium, PTH(parathyroid hormone) and pH are normal with raised alkaline phosphatase(ALP) levels.

Clinical features of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic(XLH) rickets include lower extremity abnormalities, short stature, poor growth, delayed dentition, and tooth abscesses. The wind-swept deformity is due to genu varus(leg going inward compared to the knee joint) on one side and genu valgus(leg going outward compared to the knee) on the contralateral side.

Mainstay treatment of hypophosphatemic rickets includes oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). Phosphorus supplementation is usually given in 1-3 g elemental phosphorus divided into 4–5 doses. Frequent dosing reduces diarrhoea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus. Calcitriol is administered 30–70 ng/kg/day divided into 2 doses.

Pearl PM1959: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

* Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 

* Delayed appearance of the epiphysis

* Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.

* Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.

* Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

* Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices

* In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

* Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia

* Wrist: especially the ulna

* Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: 126. For the study conducted, the Sensitivity is 8/10, and the Specificity is 7/10. Calculate the positive likelihood ratio.
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio is 8/3.

A positive likelihood ratio is the ratio of the likelihood of obtaining a positive test result in a patient with the disease to a patient who does not have the disease.

Positive likelihood ratio = Sensitivity / (1- Specificity)

In the above scenario:

* Sensitivity= 8/10

* Specificity= 7/10

Positive Likelihood ratio = (8/10) / (1-7/10) = (8/10) / (3/10) = 8/3.

Note:

A negative likelihood ratio is the ratio of the likelihood of obtaining a negative test result in a patient with the disease to a patient who does not have the disease.

Negative likelihood ratio = (1- Sensitivity) / Specificity.

questions.text:
128. Match the following syndromes with their particular neuroimaging findings.

1. Von Hippel Lindau Disease a. Unidentified Bright Objects
2. Neurofibromatosis type 1 b. Subependymal Astrocytomas
3. Tuberous sclerosis c. Hemangioblastomas
4. Sturge Weber Syndrome d. Pial capillary malformation
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d.

1. Von Hippel Lindau Disease c. Hemangioblastomas
2. Neurofibromatosis type 1 a. Unidentified Bright Objects
3. Tuberous sclerosis b. Subependymal Astrocytomas
4. Sturge Weber Syndrome d. Pial capillary malformation


In Tuberous Sclerosis, subependymal nodules along the lateral ventricular wall may calcify and project into the ventricular cavity, creating a candle-dripping appearance. While generally benign, some of the cases progress to subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. These tumours can obstruct cerebrospinal fluid circulation, leading to hydrocephalus.

Children with Neurofibromatosis type 1 are prone to neurologic complications, with MRI showing hyperintense T2-weighted signals in the optic tracts, brainstem, globus pallidus, thalamus, internal capsule, and cerebellum. These signals, known as unidentified bright objects (UBOs) or focal areas of signal abnormality, typically resolve by age 30. The pathological significance of UBOs remains unclear, and their relationship with learning disabilities, attention-deficit disorders, behavioural issues, and speech abnormalities is debated.

The major neurologic feature of von Hippel-Lindau's disease is CNS hemangioblastomas, which commonly affect the cerebellum. Patients may present with signs of increased intracranial pressure, and brain CT or MRI typically reveals a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule. Spinal hemangioblastomas, often accompanied by syringomyelia, can cause pain, and sensory, and motor changes. 

Brain MRI with contrast is the preferred imaging for assessing pial capillary malformation in Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS). White matter abnormalities, often due to chronic hypoxia, and ipsilateral atrophy are common. Calcifications are best visualised on head CT. The choroid plexus is often enlarged, with its size correlating to the extent of the leptomeningeal malformation.

questions.text: 129. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the paediatric OPD with fever, refusal to eat, and irritability for the past two days. Examination reveals multiple small vesicular lesions on the buccal mucosa, tongue along with erythematous vesicular rashes on the palms and soles. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission for this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) which is not a vector borne disease. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16 or Enterovirus 71 and is transmitted by fecal-oral route, respiratory droplets or direct contact with vesicular fluid. 

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever primarily affecting young children, marked by groups of papulovesicular eruptions on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses belong to the Picornaviridae family and are classified into groups A and B. 

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses: 

* Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD)

* Herpangina- It is a febrile vesicular pharyngitis

* Aseptic Meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses: 

* Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest.

* Orchitis, myocarditis, juvenile diabetes

questions.text:
130. A 55-year-old male patient came to the physician due to chronic fatigue. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy is noted. The findings of lymph node biopsy are shown in the image below. On immunohistochemistry, the lymphoma cells expressed CD5, CD20, and cyclin D1. Laboratory findings are given below. Which translocation is responsible for this patient's pathology?

Lab findings:

Hb: 10 g/dL

TLC: 1,40,00/mm3

Platelet: 2,26,000/mm3
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image and laboratory findings are suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma, a type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation.

Mantle cell lymphoma is a rare subtype of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is usually identified by a translocation of the CCND1 gene. It presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life and shows a male predominance. The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

Clinical features:

* Extensive painless lymphadenopathy

* B-symptoms like fevers, night sweats, and weight loss symptoms

* Splenomegaly-related discomfort

* Blood count abnormalities due to bone marrow involvement

* Symptoms related to extranodal organ involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, liver, and bone marrow

* Mucosal involvement of the small bowel or colon produces polyp-like lesions called lymphomatoid polyposis

Histopathological features:

* There is a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft nuclear contours.

* The nuclear chromatin is condensed, nucleoli are inconspicuous, and the cytoplasm is scant. 

The image given below shows a histopathology slide depicting nodular mantle cell lymphoma:



Mantle cell lymphomas have (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. These cells are positive for CD19 to CD22.

The prognosis is poor with a median survival of 3 to 4 years.

Other options:

Option B: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. Patients usually will be adolescents or young adults presenting with extranodal masses. It may sometimes present as leukemia.

Option C: t(11;22) is seen in Ewing sarcoma. It is a bone tumor presenting with swelling and tenderness over the site. Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance

Option D: t(14;18) is seen in follicular lymphoma. They present with multiple areas of painless lymphadenopathy. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes would show nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

questions.text: 131. A 42-year-old male with a history of recurrent community-acquired respiratory tract infections is prescribed azithromycin for his current exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. However, his symptoms fail to improve, and his sputum culture reveals Macrolide-resistant gram-positive cocci. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the macrolide resistance observed in this organism?

choices.text: Methylation of the ribosomal RNA (rRNA) in the 50S ribosomal subunit
Alteration of the peptidoglycan synthesis pathway, reducing drug binding
Modification of drug structure through acetylation

questions.solution:
Methylation of the ribosomal RNA (rRNA) in the 50S ribosomal subunit is most likely responsible for the macrolide resistance observed in this organism.

Macrolides exert their effect by binding to the rRNA on the 50S ribosomal subunit, inhibiting protein synthesis. Resistance can occur through methylation of the 23S rRNA, which prevents the binding of macrolides to their target site. This mechanism is the primary mechanism of resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae and other gram-positive cocci.

Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that inhibit protein synthesis by acting on the 50s subunit of the ribosome and blocking the translocation of t-RNA. They are bacteriostatic agents. Examples of Macrolides are erythromycin, azithromycin, clarithromycin, and telithromycin. 

Other mechanisms of drug resistance to Macrolides:

* Drug efflux by an active pump mechanism

* 50S Ribosomal unit is Methylated by inducible or constitutive production of methylase enzymes, which decreases drug binding - MLSB resistance

* Macrolide hydrolysis by esterases produced by Enterobacterales

* Chromosomal mutations that alter a 50S ribosomal protein in Bacillus subtilis, Campylobacter spp., mycobacteria, and gram-positive cocci.

Other options:

Option B: Transposon-mediated acquisition of the mec-A gene is an incorrect answer. Mec- A gene is responsible for resistance of S. aureus against methicillin which is a beta-lactam antibiotic and not a macrolide antibiotic.

Option C: Alteration of the peptidoglycan synthesis pathway, reducing drug binding is a mechanism of resistance typically seen in beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillins and cephalosporins). Macrolides act by binding to the ribosome, not by interacting with peptidoglycan synthesis, so this mechanism is irrelevant to macrolide resistance.

Option D: Modification of the antibiotic molecule, such as acetylation or phosphorylation, is a well-known mechanism of resistance in certain antibiotics like aminoglycosides and chloramphenicol.

questions.text: 133. A 30-year-old man, Akash, stabbed his roommate at night but had no memory of the act. Upon waking, he appeared confused and had no recollection of the act. His family reported past episodes of walking, talking, and performing routine tasks while asleep. A sleep specialist diagnosed him with a sleep disorder, with a history of similar behavior since childhood. What is Akash’s likely legal responsibility for the crime?

choices.text: Completely responsible for his crime as sleep disorders cannot be considered as defense
Not responsible for his crime due to involuntary nature of his actions
Completely responsible for his crime as he has failed to control the sleep disorder
Partially responsible for his crime due to temporary mental disturbance

questions.solution:
In this scenario, Akash is not responsible for his crime due to the involuntary nature of his actions. His actions are likely a result of somnambulism, which is a type of sleep disorder.

Somnambulism is characterized by incomplete arousal from sleep, during which a person may walk, act, or even commit serious acts like theft or murder in a dissociated state. Such acts are not premeditated, and the person has no awareness or memory of the actions. Since the law views mens rea (guilty intent) as a crucial element of a crime, such a person is not criminally responsible for his acts.

Automatism refers to actions performed by an individual whose level of consciousness is significantly impaired, leading to a lack of full awareness of their behavior. This condition involves seemingly intentional and complex actions carried out without conscious control, often followed by memory loss (amnesia). Criminal courts recognize several causes of automatism, including 

* Epilepsy (classified as mentally ill automatism)

* Concussion or brain disease

* Hypoglycemia

* Somnambulism (classified as non-mentally ill automatism).

Pearl PM2059: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: 134. An extract of the flowers derived from the plant given below is used as a mosquito control measure. Which of the following best describes the action of this insecticide?
questions.solution:
The given plant is pyrethrum (Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium). The extract from the flowers contains pyrethrin (nerve poison) which is used as an excellent space spray against adult mosquitos. 

Space sprays are those where the insecticidal formulation is sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog to kill insects.

Pyrethrum sprays are effective in reducing the number of mosquitoes but the reduction is only temporary since it has no residual action like DDT or other synthetic insecticides. So, most space sprays contain pyrethrum and DDT for synergistic action.

Pearl PM1686: Insecticides

Contact poisons

* Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils

* Synthetic:

* Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.

* Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.

* Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.

* Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.

* Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin

* Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.

* Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.

Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.


Pearl PM1669: Mosquito Control Measures

* Anti-larval measures

* Environmental control

* This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.

* Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control

* Chemical control

* Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.

* Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.

* Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.

* Biological control

* The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.

* These are used in conjunction with other methods.

* Anti-adult measures

* Residual sprays

* Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)

* Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes

* Space sprays

* Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.

* Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.

* Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.

* Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.

* Protection against bites

* Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: 135. A Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test was performed to assess bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics. Which is the most accurate statement regarding the antibiotics at positions 1, 2, and 3?

choices.text: 1 - Bacteria have developed resistance to the antibiotic
2- Antibiotic is not placed on agar properly, leading to inaccurate result
3- Antibiotic is highly effective but has slow diffusion in agar
2- Antibiotic can be effective if used at higher doses

questions.solution:
Based on the image, antibiotic at position 2 is intermediately susceptible and could still be effective if used in higher than normal doses to enhance its activity.

Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method is a kind of antibiotic susceptibility test where the bacterium’s broth culture is evenly spread over the surface of a solid medium, and the plate is left to dry after which 4-6 antibiotic discs are carefully placed on the agar using sterile forceps. The plate is then incubated overnight, and the effectiveness of each antibiotic is assessed by measuring the clear zones (zones of inhibition) around the discs. These zones indicate bacterial susceptibility, with larger zones showing sensitivity to the antibiotic and the absence or minimal zone indicating resistance.

The size of the zone of inhibition depends on various factors, including the antibiotic’s diffusion, disc potency, and bacterial susceptibility. Based on the size of zone of inhibition, a bacterium can be: 

* Susceptible when the antibiotic inhibits bacterial growth. Here at position 1, the zone of inhibition is quite large, suggesting that the bacteria are susceptible to the antibiotic and there is no evidence of resistance. (Option A)

* Intermediately Susceptible when the bacteria is susceptible to the drug at higher than normal dosages. Here at position 2, the smaller zone suggests intermediate susceptibility and increasing the dose could enhance its antimicrobial activity. It does not indicate incorrect placement of the disk. (Option B)

* Resistant when the bacteria is not affected by the drug due to the presence of specific resistance mechanisms. Here at position 3, there is absent or minimal zone indicating the bacteria is resistant to the antibiotic. (Option C)

questions.text:
136. A 6-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive, generalized hypotonia, and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray showed massive cardiomegaly. Muscle biopsy findings and the lab results are given below. Which of the following enzymes can be used for successful enzyme replacement therapy of this disease?

Muscle enzyme assay- low levels of acid maltase level

Genetic testing- mutation of the GAA gene sequence
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing large vacuoles filled with glycogen suggest the diagnosis of Pompe's disease. Myozyme or alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase, can be used for enzyme replacement therapy of this disease

Pompe's disease is also known as type 2 glycogen storage disorder. It is autosomal recessive and occurs due to a mutation of the GAA gene on chromosome 17. This gene codes for alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme that catalyzes the alpha 1,4 and 1,6 glycogen linkage. 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various cells. It begins with accumulation in peripheral, voluntary muscles and progresses to involve the cardiac muscle and diaphragm. 

Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding. Late involvement of the diaphragm leads to respiratory failure. Cardiac involvement can lead to arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy. 

Laboratory investigations will reveal elevated serum creatine kinase, aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase. Urine glucose tetrasaccharide is a glycogen breakdown product that can be used to assess severity of disease and response to treatment. 

Myozyme can prevent worsening or can reverse cardiac and skeletal abnormalities. Administering methotrexate, rituximab, and intravenous immunoglobulin can prevent the immune tolerance that may develop to myozyme or enzyme replacement therapy.

Other options:

Option A - Aldurazyme (laronidase) is used to treat Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C - Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Option D - Elaprase is used in the treatment of Hunter Syndrome, mucopolysaccharidosis II. It is characterized by large round cheeks, broad nose, macroglossia, hoarse voice, sleep apnea, macrocephaly, hydrocephaly, and ocular problems.

questions.text: 137. A 2-day-old newborn was referred after newborn screening, which detected a TSH of 45 mIU/L. The baby was born at term via an uncomplicated delivery, has normal feeding and activity, and shows no dysmorphic features. A repeat confirmatory venous sample after 72 hours confirms TSH of 45 mIU/L. Examination reveals no significant abnormalities. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Observe and repeat TSH in 2 weeks
Obtain a thyroid ultrasound before initiating treatment

questions.solution:
The newborn has screening-detected congenital hypothyroidism (TSH >40 mIU/L), which requires immediate levothyroxine treatment to prevent neurodevelopmental impairment.

Most infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth due to transplacental passage of maternal T4, which provides about one-third of normal fetal thyroid hormone levels. Symptoms, if present, may include:

* Prolonged jaundice

* Poor feeding

* Lethargy

* Constipation

* Macroglossia

* Umbilical hernia

* Cold, mottled skin

Newborn screening is done via heel prick between 1 and 5 days of life, typically measuring TSH. Affected infants usually have low T4 and elevated TSH. A confirmatory venous sample needs to be collected after 72 hours if initial TSH>20mIU/L.  According to the latest IAP guidelines on managing congenital hypothyroidism, if:

* TSH > 40, immediate treatment with levothyroxine is initiated alongside imaging for etiological diagnosis.

* TSH is between 20–40; further categorization is done based on T4 levels.

* T4 is low with high TSH, levothyroxine is started, and imaging is performed.

* T4 is low with normal TSH; it suggests central hypothyroidism, and levothyroxine is also initiated.

* Normal T4 but high TSH requires repeat testing after two weeks, and if TSH remains persistently >10 after three weeks, levothyroxine is started.

* Normal TSH and T4 require no treatment.

Levothyroxine (10–15 mcg/kg/day) is the treatment of choice. Although T3 is the active form, most circulating T3 is derived from T4 conversion, making LT4 sufficient. Rapid normalization of thyroid levels within 2 weeks is crucial for neurodevelopment. Undertreatment is linked to adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes, including decreased IQ.

questions.text: 138. A surgeon injured the facial nerve just below the geniculate ganglion while operating on a patient for stapedectomy. Which of the following tests will be preserved?
questions.solution:
Schirmer test will be preserved in this condition.

Schirmer test is a lacrimation test. A strip of filter paper is hooked in the lower fornix of each eye, and the amount of wetting of the strip is measured. Decreased lacrimation will be seen in a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion as the secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland leave at the geniculate ganglion via the greater superficial petrosal nerve. 

The course of the facial nerve can be divided into three parts:

* Intracranial Part- From pons to internal acoustic meatus 

* Intratemporal Part- From internal acoustic meatus to stylomastoid foramen. It is further divided into:

*

* Meatal segment- Within internal acoustic meatus.

* Labyrinthine segment- From the fundus of the meatus to the geniculate ganglion, where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a “genu”. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter, and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest.

* Tympanic or horizontal segment- From the geniculate ganglion to just above the pyramidal eminence. It lies above the oval window and below the lateral semicircular canal

* Mastoid (vertical segment)- From the pyramid to stylomastoid foramen. The second genu of the nerve is present between the tympanic and mastoid segments.

* Extracranial Part- From stylomastoid foramen to the termination of its peripheral branches.



Other options:

Options B, C and D: Stapedial reflex, Salivary flow test and Taste test, all these tests will be absent since the nerves lie below the site of the lesion which is the geniculate ganglion.

Nerve to stapedius is responsible for the stapedial reflex, chorda tympani is responsible for the taste test and salivary flow test.

questions.text: 139. Marshall's triad in a bomb explosion is seen due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Marshall's triad in a bomb explosion is seen due to secondary blast injuries.

Marshall described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions. It includes:

* Abrasions

* Bruises/ contusions

* Puncture lacerations

Blast injuries are classified as:

* Primary injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures. External injuries are absent and are characterized by internal injuries. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible to this.

* Secondary injuries- injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.

* Tertiary injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.

* Quaternary injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, gas, etc.

* The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.

* When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.

* Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.

* Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: 140. Which of the following food materials or toxins is correctly paired with the disease it is known to cause?
questions.solution:
Argemone oil - Epidemic dropsy is the accurate pairing among all.

Epidemic dropsy is a condition caused by the consumption of mustard oil contaminated with argemone oil. This contamination, either accidental or intentional, introduces the toxic alkaloid sanguinarine, which disrupts pyruvic acid oxidation.

Clinically, it presents with sudden, non-inflammatory swelling of the legs, often accompanied by diarrhea, and can progress to dyspnea, cardiac failure, and even glaucoma. While affecting all age groups except breast-fed infants, it carries a variable mortality rate. Prevention hinges on eliminating argemone weeds from mustard crops and rigorous enforcement against adulteration.

Other options:

Option (A) Lathyrism is caused by Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) found in L. sativus (Khesari dal). Furthermore, infantile cirrhosis is associated with Aflatoxin B1.

Option (C) Crotalaria (locally known as Jhunjhunia) seeds were found to contain pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are hepatotoxins. This causes endemic ascites. 

Option (D) Foodgrains such as bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get infested during the flowering stages by the ergot fungus (Claviceps purpurea). Consumption of ergot infested grain leads to ergotism.

questions.text: 141. A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure for obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts, not split-thickness skin grafts.

The most preferable donor site is the buttocks in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

* The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.

* Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take.’ It can further be meshed to allow expansion.

* Grafts will take up only the beds that are vascularized; hence, preparing the wound bed is an essential step.

* Skin grafts completely depend on nutrition in the tissue in which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.

* A clean, healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.

* The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.

* The donor area is dressed appropriately, and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average graft thickness obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.



Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

* Large grafts can be harvested.

* In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.

* Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 

* Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

* It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction

* Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Pearl PM2297: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

* Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.

* Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.

* Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: 142. A woman presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb, as shown below. On examination, there is non-pitting edema associated with the thickening of the skin. Which type of biological transmission is seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive unilateral lower limb edema, which is non-pitting and associated with thickening of the skin, is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. The microfilaria of the causative agent W. bancrofti undergoes cyclo-developmental biological transmission. 

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of Wuchereria bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. It undergoes only developmental changes and no multiplication in the vector, known as cyclo-developmental transmission.

Epidemiological classification of vector-borne diseases by methods in which vectors are involved in the transmission and propagation of parasites : 

Mechanical transmission: Here, an arthropod carries the infectious agent by either crawling or flying or is excreted by the vector at the site of infection. The infectious organism does not undergo multiplication or development during its transmission by the vector.

Biological transmission: The vector serves as a site for development, multiplication, or both for the infectious agent. It is of three types :

* Propagative

* Cyclo-propagative

* Cyclo-developmental

The image below demonstrates the life-cyle of Wuchereria bancrofti:



Pearl PM0495: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

* The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.

* E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

* The agent changes in form and in number.

* E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

* The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.

* E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

* Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.

* E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

* The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.

* E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: 143. A 68-year-old patient presents with progressive Parkinson-like features, including asymmetric rigidity, an "alien limb" phenomenon, and difficulty performing learned motor tasks (apraxia). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Corticobasal Syndrome is the correct answer as it is characterized by asymmetric rigidity and akinesia, often with dystonia and myoclonus. The "alien limb" phenomenon and apraxia are specific cortical signs strongly associated with it.

Corticobasal syndrome (CBS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by asymmetric rigidity, dystonia, myoclonus, and apraxia, often leading to an "alien limb" phenomenon. While clinically recognized as CBS, it can pathologically stem from various tauopathies, including corticobasal degeneration (CBD), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), frontotemporal lobar degeneration-TDP (FTLD-TDP), and even Alzheimer's disease (AD).

Clinically, CBS progresses to bilateral involvement, dysarthria, gait disturbances, and frontal-predominant dementia. Currently, treatment remains symptomatic, as no disease-modifying therapies exist.

Other options:

Option (A) Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) : While MSA can have Parkinsonian features, it is primarily characterized by autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence) and cerebellar ataxia. Asymmetric rigidity can be present, but the "alien limb" phenomenon and apraxia are not typical.

Option (B) Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP): PSP is characterized by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, early postural instability with falls, and axial rigidity. Although it can have bradykinesia and rigidity, it does not typically include apraxia or the "alien limb" phenomenon. 

Option (D) Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB): DLB is characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and REM sleep-behaviour disorder. While parkinsonian features are present, cortical signs like apraxia and the "alien limb" phenomenon are not core features of DLB.

questions.text: 144. Which of the following statements is correct in accordance with the given pathway?

choices.text: Impulses from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus are relayed to the otic ganglion
Afferent fibres reach the mesencephalic nucleus of the fifth nerve
Optic radiation relays impulses to the striate cortex
The optic tract carries impulses to the medial geniculate body

questions.solution:
Optic radiation relays impulses to the striate cortex in the accommodation pathway shown in the image.

The near reflex is a combination of convergence, accommodation and miosis.

In the pathway of accommodation reflex:

* The afferent impulses from the retina reach the striate cortex via the optic nerve, optic chiasma, optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and optic radiations.

* From the striate cortex, impulses are relayed to the para striate cortex and then to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus via the occipitomesencephalic tract and the pontine centre.

* The efferent impulses travel along the 3rd nerve from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and relay in the accessory and ciliary ganglion.

* These impulses then reach the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle.





Other options:

Option A: Impulses from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus are relayed to the accessory and ciliary ganglion.

Option B: Afferent fibres reach the mesencephalic nucleus of the fifth nerve in the convergence reflex.

Option D: The optic tract carries impulses to the lateral geniculate body.

questions.text: 145. The life table analysis calculated under Reproductive and Child Health program in a district is done for assessing:
questions.solution:
The life table analysis is done to assess the efficacy of contraceptives. 

Contraceptive efficacy is generally assessed by two methods - the pearl index and life table analysis.

* Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

* Life table analysis calculates a failure rate for each month of use. A cumulative failure rate can then compare methods for any length of exposure. 

Option A: Net Reproduction Rate is calculated to assess the reproductive performance of the population. If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate. It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.  NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2-child norm.

Option B: The Couple Protection Rate is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community. It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

Option D: An unmet need for family planning refers to a situation where sexually active individuals, particularly women, want to avoid pregnancy but are not using any contraceptive methods.

Pearl PM1715: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).



* In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.

* In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

* It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.

* It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

* Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: 146. The spirochete structure responsible for corkscrew motility is found where?

choices.text: Between outer membrane and peptidoglycan layer
Between peptidoglycan layer and inner membrane

questions.solution:
The endoflagella, responsible for producing corkscrew motility in spirochetes is located in the periplasmic space between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan layer.

Spirochetes are Gram-negative bacteria, but their cell wall differs from other Gram-negative bacteria by the presence of endoflagella. Endoflagella (axial filament) do not protrude outside the organism (Option A) but are present in the periplasmic space between the outer membrane and peptidoglycan layer. The endoflagella that begin at each end, wind around, and overlap at the midpoint of the spirochete.

The endoflagella covers the inner membrane (Option C and D) which provides osmotic stability and covers the protoplasm.



Endoflagella are responsible for various types of motility such as flexion-extension, corkscrew-like rotation, and translatory movement. Corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis is shown below.

questions.text: 147. A newborn boy has microcephaly, cutis aplasia, microphthalmia, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, and rocker-bottom feet. Brain imaging shows a single midline ventricle and absent olfactory bulbs. Which developmental defect best explains his CNS abnormalities?

choices.text: Abnormal development of the first pharyngeal arch

questions.solution:
The newborn’s findings—microcephaly, cutis aplasia, microphthalmia, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet—are characteristic of Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome). The key neurological defect, holoprosencephaly, results from failure of the prosencephalon (forebrain) cleavage during weeks 5-6 of development. 

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) is a genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13, leading to severe midline defects due to impaired forebrain (prosencephalon) division during early embryogenesis. It is characterized by holoprosencephaly, microcephaly, absent olfactory bulbs, and a single midline ventricle.

Facial anomalies include microphthalmia, cleft lip/palate, and cutis aplasia. Other features include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects (e.g., VSD, PDA), renal anomalies (e.g., polycystic kidneys), and scalp defects. 

Other options:

Option A: Defective neural tube closure is associated with neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, spina bifida), not forebrain division.

Option C: Failure of neural crest migration is associated with craniofacial syndromes like DiGeorge syndrome, not holoprosencephaly.

Option D: Abnormal first pharyngeal arch development leads to conditions like Treacher Collins syndrome, affecting the mandible and ear structures.

questions.text: 148. A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of hypopigmentation of the skin. On examination, there was hypopigmentation of the iris. Investigations reveal neutropenia. A peripheral smear was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils, which along with oculocutaneous albinism, and neutropenia is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding a protein known as lysosomal trafficking regulator. There is a defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and susceptibility to infections.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These include:

* Significant pyogenic infections

* Albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes)

* Neurological abnormalities

questions.text: 149. An elderly male patient was found to have hallucinations and vivid dreams following induction with an intravenous anesthetic agent. Which among the following is the most effective drug to reduce the incidence and severity of these post-operative reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of emergence reaction or delirium most commonly associated with ketamine. Benzodiazepines are the most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these postoperative reactions.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine during emergence from anesthesia are vivid dreaming, hallucinations, extracorporeal experiences, and delusions associated with confusion, euphoria, and fear. These reactions occur in individuals with psychological susceptibility and when large doses of ketamine are rapidly administered. 

Benzodiazepines (BZD) act by facilitating the action of GABA receptors. It acts by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels, thereby hyperpolarizing the neurons and inhibiting their activity.

Uses of Benzodiazepines include

* Antiepileptics: Lorazepam is the drug of choice for status epilepticus, delirium tremens, catatonia, and patients with liver dysfunction

* Generalized anxiety disorders, panic disorders

* Intravenous induction agent - Lorazepam

* Sedative premedication in children - Midazolam

* Muscle relaxant 

Other options: 

Option A: Phenobarbitone is a barbiturate primarily used in the treatment of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures.

Option B: Flumazenil is the benzodiazepine antagonist and is used in BZD overdose.

Option D: Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic used in the management of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It is also used in bipolar disorder and in trigeminal neuralgias.

150. A 55-year-old morbidly obese diabetic woman presents with a history of failed metformin therapy. She is started on canagliflozin. Which of the following side effects are associated with canagliflozin?

* Urinary tract infections

* Weight gain

* Increased risk of fractures

* Increased risk of lower extremity amputation
questions.solution:
The side effects associated with canagliflozin are urinary tract infections, increased risk of fractures, and lower extremity amputations.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. It is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of diabetic ketoacidosis.

It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations. Since SGLT2 inhibitors depend on the rate of glucose filtration to be effective, potency decreases if given in stage 3 kidney disease (GFR 60–30 mL/min).

SGLT2 inhibitors can cause mild weight loss and reduction in blood pressure. Drugs like empagliflozin and canagliflozin are found to reduce major cardiovascular events.

questions.text: 151. A patient with a kidney transplant presented with a lymphocele around the transplanted kidney. The patient provides a list of drugs that have been used by her after the transplant. Which of the given drugs, the likely cause of this complication, prevents the progression of the cell cycle from the G1 to S phase and thus arrests T-cell proliferation?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, Sirolimus prevents the progression of the cell cycle at the G1-S transition and inhibits T-cell activation and proliferation. It is known to cause lymphocele as a side effect.

Sirolimus, also known as Rapamycin belongs to a group of immunosuppressant drugs termed Proliferation Signal Inhibitors(PSI), along with Everolimus. These drugs bind to circulating immunophilin FK506­ binding protein 12 and create an active complex that goes on to inhibit mTOR, the mammalian target of Rapamycin.

mTOR is a key regulator of interleukin-mediated T-cell proliferation. Blocking the action of mTOR results in the arrest of the Tcell activation and proliferation in the G1-S phase transition. Side effects of Sirolimus include:

* Lymphocele: a collection of lymphatic fluid around the transplanted kidney that appears in a dose-dependent fashion and requires close post-operative monitoring.

* Delayed wound healing

* Anaemia, thrombocytopenia, leucopenia

* Hypokalemia

* Oral ulcers, GI side effects 

* Increased risk of infections

Other Options:

Option B and C: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus are termed calcineurin inhibitors. They are not known to cause lymphocele. Cyclosporine binds to cyclophilin, an immunophilin molecule and this complex inhibits a cytoplasmic phosphatase known as calcineurin. Calcineurin is responsible for the activation of NF-KB, a transcription factor in T-cells responsible for the synthesis of interleukins like IL-2, which send proliferative signals to other T-cells.

Hence, cyclosporine-induced block of NF-KB activation reduces pro-proliferative interleukin signals. Tacrolimus is a much more potent calcineurin inhibitor that binds to FKPB instead of cyclophilin, which in turn blocks NF-KB activation via calcineurin inhibition. 

Option D: Muromonab is a mouse anti-human monoclonal antibody against the CD3 receptor. It causes internalization of this T-cell receptor by endocytosis which prevents proliferative signals from being received by the Tcell. It is no longer favored due to its side effects of cytokine release syndrome and pulmonary edema. Another drug in the same class, Teplizumab is under trial.

questions.text: 152. An elderly male smoker underwent a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan for parotid swelling before undergoing a parotidectomy, as shown below. What histopathological change best accounts for this imaging finding shown below?

choices.text: Cribriform growth pattern resembling Swiss cheese
Squamous cells with large mucous vacuoles

questions.solution:
The given Technetium 99- pertechnate scan for parotid swelling in an elderly male smoker shows a hot nodule, indicating Warthin's tumor. The histopathological feature seen in this condition is oncocytic cells in two layers.

Oncocytes are large cells with abundant mitochondria imparting a granular, eosinophilic appearance to the cytoplasm with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli. These oncocytes are FDG PET avid and also show up as hot nodules on the pertechnate scan because of the high content of mitochondria in these cells. Thus oncocytomas of the salivary gland also show up as hot nodules.

questions.text: 153. A forensic investigator is examining skeletal remains to estimate the age of an individual. Which of the following ossification centers is the last to fuse in a human body?
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, the medial end of the clavicle is the last ossification center to fuse.

Radiological estimation of age can be done by assessing the fusion of major bones occurring progressively:

*

* 15 years: Fusion of triradiate cartilage.

* 16-17 years: Medial epicondyle of humerus

* 18-19 years: Fusion of epiphysis around knee, shoulder, and wrist joints.

* 20-21 years: Fusion of epiphysis around Iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, medial end of the clavicle.

Note: Fusion in females occurs about one year earlier than in males.

questions.text: 154. A 15-month-old toddler presents for routine vaccination. You plan to administer a vaccine that contains killed virus particles to provide immunity. Which of the following vaccines will you most likely administer?

choices.text: Diphtheria, Tetanus, and acellular Pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
The killed vaccine among all the options is the Hepatitis A vaccine.

It contains killed (inactivated) hepatitis A virus particles, which stimulate an immune response to provide immunity against the virus without causing disease.

IAP recommends giving this vaccine to all children after 12 months of age.

Other options:

Option A: The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant DNA vaccine, which contains only the HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) protein. 

Option B: The DTaP vaccine is a subunit vaccine containing specific bacterial toxins (e.g., diphtheria and tetanus toxoids) and parts of the Bordetella pertussis bacteria. 

Option D: The Varicella vaccine (chickenpox) is a live attenuated virus vaccine, which contains weakened (but live) varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: 155. A 70-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. Which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: Infarct myocardium appears brick red due to loss of LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears brick red due to preserved LDH activity
Infarct myocardium appears unstained due to preserved LDH activity
Viable myocardium appears unstained due to the loss of LDH activity

questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick-red color to the viable non-infarcted myocardium due to preserved LDH activity.

Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution.

The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

questions.text:
156. An ophthalmologist does the test shown below while evaluating a case of squint. What is the utility of this test?

BSV - Binocular single vision

ARC - Anomalous retinal correspondence

choices.text: To measure direction and degree of deviation
To differentiate between BSV, ARC and suppression

questions.solution:
The given image shows  Worth's four-dot test done to differentiate between Binocular single vision (BSV), Anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC) and suppression. It is a sensory function test. It is performed as mentioned below:

* Patient wears goggles with

* Red lens: Right eye

* Green lens: Left eye

* A box is viewed having 4 lights: one red, two green, and one white

* Inference:

* A: Normal—All 4 lights seen

* B: Abnormal retinal correspondence—All 4 lights seen in the presence of manifest squint

* C: Left Suppression—2 red lights seen

* D: Right suppression—3 green lights seen

* E: Diplopia—5 lights seen (2 red, 3 green)

ARC occurs as sensory adaptation in case of small angle squint whereas in diplopia corresponding points change. Over of the normal eye corresponds with the extra foveal point of a slightly deviated eye to adapt for diplopia. 

Suppression occurs as sensory adaptation in confusion where 2 images are formed. The brain will suppress the image from the deviated eye. 

Other options :

Option A: To measure direction and degree of deviation we use Hirschberg's test. It gives a rough estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is used to shine light from an arm's distance and the patient is asked to fixate. The corneal reflection of the light will be decentered in the squinting eye in the direction opposite to the deviation.



Option B: To measure heterophoria and cyclophoria we use Maddox rod. It consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. It is a macular function test.



Option D: To assess ocular motility we use Hess chart. It is use to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing a binocular single vision field. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

questions.text: 157. Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved is known as cost-effective analysis.

In cost-effective analysis, the benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (e.g., the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. However, in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis.

Other options:

Option A: Cost-benefit analysis- Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Option C: Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities that should be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Option D: Input-output analysis: The amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, the term "input" refers to all health-related activities that consume resources, and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.

questions.text: 158. A 45-year-old male with asthma, migratory pulmonary infiltrates, and mononeuritis multiplex shows eosinophilia. A lung biopsy, as shown in the image, reveals eosinophilic infiltration and necrotizing vasculitis. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is not associated with c-ANCA.

The patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) have circulating ANCA that is usually anti-myeloperoxidase. This means that when ANCA is present in Churg-Strauss, it is typically p-ANCA (anti-myeloperoxidase), not c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3). Whereas, c-ANCA is associated with Granulomatosis With Polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis).

The image shows a histological section with characteristic features of Churg-Strauss Syndrome (Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis - EGPA). The image shows:

Eosinophilic infiltration: The dense, pinkish areas are likely eosinophils, a hallmark of EGPA. Granulomatous inflammation: The central area appears to be a granuloma, a collection of immune cells. Vasculitis: The surrounding tissue shows evidence of inflammation around blood vessels, suggesting vasculitis.



Other options:

Option A) Problems with the sinuses, such as rhinitis and sinusitis, are frequently observed in patients with Churg-Strauss, often appearing early in the disease's progression.

Option C)  Heart-related issues, including myocarditis, pericarditis, and coronary vasculitis, can occur and are a significant cause of mortality in the patients having Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option D) Churg-Strauss syndrome is strongly associated with development of focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

questions.text: 160. Which of the following bacteria are difficult to be identified on gram stain?
questions.solution:
Rickettsiae cannot be identified on gram stain.

Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are gram-negative but do not stain well on gram-stain. They are readily visible under the light microscope when stained with Giemsa stain, acridine orange, or other stains. They are non-motile and non-capsulated. 

Other options:

Option A: Bordetella is a gram-negative small, ovoid coccobacillus.

Option B: Serratia is gram-negative and pleomorphic in the form of minute coccobacillus and rods. 

Option D: Bacillus anthracis is gram-positive but tends to be decolourised easily to appear gram-variable or even gram-negative.

questions.text: 161. A 24-year-old male was diagnosed as HIV positive and was started on ART. Now, he started complaining of acute left-sided flank pain and haematuria. His urine routine workup showed RBCs and pus cells. IVP was planned and the plain film didn’t show any opacity. The 15-minute post-contrast image is shown below. What would be the most likely cause of his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
The answer is protease inhibitor-induced nephrolithiasis. Protease inhibitors such as Indinavir, when given as part of antiretroviral therapy, can cause radiolucent stones that are missed on CT/X-ray and may cause hydronephrosis due to obstruction, as seen here on the left side.

In this IVP, the dye is seen pooling in the aberrant left pelvicalyceal system as late as 15 minutes post-contrast. The calyces appear dilated, indicating hydronephrosis, the most probable cause of which must be a lucent stone such as indinavir induced stone.

Nephrolithiasis or kidney stones are an important cause for flank pain and can be classified radiologically as either radioopaque or radiolucent stones. Radioopaque stones are calcium-based stones such as calcium oxalate, followed by slightly more lucent struvite and cystine followed by uric acid stones which may be opaque(due to calcium coating) or mostly lucent, followed by drug-induced stones that are radiolucent. Cardinal features of various stones causing urolithiasis are given:

* Calcium oxalate: Most common type, precipitated by hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, hypercalcemia, hyperuricosuria and hypocitraturia. The most common disease process is hyperparathyroidism.

* Calcium phosphate: Seen as apatite( in infection) or brushite (distal RTA)stones.

* Uric acid: Stone formation occurs in acidic urine and additionally promotes calcium oxalate deposition on the uric acid stone. Seen in gout, myeloproliferative diseases etc.

* Infection associated: Struvite( magnesium ammonium phosphate) and apatite stones seen, in alkaline urine formed by urease producing organisms like Klebsiella, Proteus, Serratia, Enterobacter etc. Staghorn calculi are unique struvite stones that form like a cast of the pelvicalycal system.

* Cystine stones: Very hard and form in acidic urine.

Patients present with pain radiating from the flank to the groin or flank pain and difficulty and pain on urination, hematuria, pyuria, etc. The initial investigation may be with USG and/or X-ray KUB which is better as over three-fourths of all stones are radioopaque and visualized. The preferred investigation for diagnosis of nephrolithiasis is a non-contrast CT scan which can be used for both radiolucent and radiopaque stones except indinavir. 

Hydronephrosis is an aseptic dilation of the pelvicalyceal system due to various degrees of obstruction to the flow of urine. On USG, it is graded based on the changes to the calyx. The cup-shaped calyx becomes blunted, following which it becomes club-shaped and finally becomes broadened in severe disease. On IVU, the normal pelvicalyceal architecture is seen as lost and the calyces may be blunted or broadened. The contrast dye takes longer than usual to drain from the pelvicalyx.

Other Options:

Option A: Cystinuria-induced nephrolithiasis is a genetic disorder (Autosomal Recessive) due to the mutations in the SLC3A1 and SLC7A9 genes, causing excess cystine in the urine. This leads to poorly soluble cystine stones in the kidneys causing nephrolithiasis. The Stones are radio-opaque and, hence should be visualized on X-ray.

Option B: Hypercalciuria-induced nephrolithiasis will present with a radiopaque stone, not radiolucent, so a normal plain X-ray rules it out. 

Option D: Struvite nephrolithiasis, often termed 'infection stones,' arises from urinary tract infections by urease-producing bacteria, primarily Proteus mirabilis. These organisms elevate urine pH, favoring magnesium ammonium phosphate crystallization. Rapid stone growth, forming staghorn calculi which are radio-opaque can lead to renal obstruction and subsequent parenchymal damage. Management requires complete stone removal and targeted antibiotic therapy to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: 162. A patient with chronic depression who was previously unresponsive to a combination of four antidepressant drugs underwent a new intervention to manage his disease. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the device shown:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray image shows a Vagus nerve stimulator (VNS) with an electrode attached to the left vagus. VNS can be used as an adjunct to manage chronic depression that is not controlled after the adequate use of four anti-depressant drugs.

VNS is an emerging modality for managing pharmacological treatment-resistant depression, especially in concomitant bipolar disorder whereby electrodes are placed over the left vagus nerve which is stimulated using a device implanted subcutaneously in the chest. Thus VNS has two parts, the vagus lead and the impulse generator.

The left vagus is chosen as the right vagus supplies the SA node, and stimulating it may cause arrhythmia. Proven indications for VNS are pharmaco-resistant epilepsy and pharmaco-resistant depression with several off-label indications under investigation. The mechanism of action is not yet fully understood.

Complications after the procedure are few and include hoarseness of voice, dyspnea, voice alteration, and cough. The VNS is battery-operated, and batteries need to be changed every 3-5 years. Nowadays a non-invasive handheld VNS is also available.

Other Options:

Option B: ECT or Electroconvulsive therapy is a tried and tested, effective management for treatment-resistant depression. Its other indications are acute manic episodes in bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, catatonia, and pregnant, depressed women who cannot take medications. It involves the generation of a generalized cerebral seizure under IV sedation or general anesthesia for a short duration. Multiple sessions may be administered and anti-depressive action may last for years. 

The current is delivered via electrodes that are placed on the scalp and connected to a generator device externally as shown in the image given below:



Option C: rTMS or repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation is a method to induce electrical impulses in focal areas of the brain without utilizing an electrode by keeping a magnetic coil and alternating the magnetic field in that coil to generate electric impulses in the brain.

It is indicated in patients who have failed to achieve therapeutic success in the treatment of major depressive disorder with at least one antidepressant drug or as an alternative to ECT in resistant depression. It does not require anesthesia and is quite safe, although it rarely may induce a seizure.



Option D: TENS, or transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, is a modality used to stimulate nerves and is not used for the treatment of depression. It involves the placement of electrode pads on the skin, and its most recognized indication is in the treatment of chronic pain conditions. The image is shown below:



Other nonpharmacological approaches that involve stimulation of the brain in depression are:

*  Deep brain stimulation (DBS)

* Transcranial direct current stimulation (TDCS)

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

* Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.

* Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

* Treatment-resistant depression

* Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)

* Depression with psychotic features

* Depressed suicidal pregnant women

* Refusal to eat or drink

* Imminent risk for suicide

* Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

* Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

* Retrograde amnesia (most common)

* Partial anterograde amnesia

* Disorientation

* Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

* Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction

* Space occupying brain lesion

* Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: 163. X is an amino acid that links the Krebs cycle and the Urea cycle. X is unable to combine with a urea cycle intermediate due to a Citrin mitochondrial transporter defect. Identify X :
questions.solution:
X is Aspartate. The urea cycle intermediate that aspartate is unable to combine with, in a Citrin transporter defect is Citrulline. This disease is termed Type 2 Citrullinemia.

The Urea cycle is linked closely to the Krebs cycle via Aspartate and Fumarate. Together, these cycles form the "Urea Bicycle". Aspartate reacts with Citrulline in the urea cycle to form Argininosuccinate, which is broken down into Fumarate and Arginine. The Fumarate is converted to Malate which becomes Oxaloacetate which can be aminated to form Asparate. The Aspartate can be reused in the Urea cycle.

Citrin is a mitochondrial transporter responsible for shuttling aspartate from the intermembrane space of the mitochondria to the cytosol. Citrin transporter defect causes Aspartate to accumulate in mitochondria and Citrulline cannot combine with it to form Argininosuccinate.

This is called Type 2 Citrullinemia as opposed to Type 1 where there is a deficiency of the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase. Clinical features of Type 2 Citrullinemia are detailed below.

It is a recessive mutation in mitochondrial aspartate-glutamate carrier-Citrin (ACG2) which causes the urea cycle to halt and reduces the transfer of NADH via malate aspartate shuttle. Mutations occur in the SLC25A13 gene on chromosome  7q21.3. The usual presentation is abrupt onset in adulthood(20-50) with recurrent attacks of hyperammonemia and its features, primarily related to CNS symptoms like altered mentation, convulsions, coma-like state, etc 

Avoidance of carbohydrate-rich foods that trigger symptoms( due to an increase in NADH) and a preference for meat, fish, and eggs is typically seen in patients. Other triggers include surgery, alcohol consumption, and medications like paracetamol. Death occurs by cerebral edema within a few years from onset if left untreated.

Diagnosis is by assays that show elevated citrulline, arginine and ammonia with near-normal levels of glutamine. Galactose-1- phosphate levels are increased in RBCs. Confirmation of the diagnosis is by identifying a mutation in the gene.

Treatment options include avoidance of carbohydrates and a diet high in protein and fat. Supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides, arginine, and pyruvate has been shown to prevent attacks in the short term. The long-term solution is a liver transplant.

Other Options:

Options A and B: Hyperammonemia in Urea cycle disorders causes the increased conversion of NH3 to Glutamate which is converted to Glutamine. This is the basis of using Phenylbutyrate to treat hyperammonemia. Phenylbutyrate is converted to phenylacetate which sequesters glutamine which can be excreted in urine. 

Option D: Arginine is one of the intermediates in the urea cycle.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 164. A 28-year-old patient presents with rapidly progressing symmetric ascending paralysis for 2 days. Findings of nerve conduction studies are consistent with demyelination. He is found to have an elevated protein level in his CSF. A provisional diagnosis of autoimmune polyradiculoneuropathy is made. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillian-Barre syndrome (GBS). High-dose steroids have no role in the management of GBS in spite of it being an autoimmune disease.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness.

Pearl PM1628: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

* B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.

* Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM

* The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.

* Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.

* The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.

* These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.
