* Diabetes mellitus

* Idiopathic pandysautonomia (may be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome)

* Porphyria

* HIV-related autonomic neuropathy

* Vincristine and other chemotherapeutic agents

questions.text: 165. A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive decreased visual acuity in both eyes associated with pain on eye movement. She has a history of transverse myelitis treated with steroids. Examination reveals bilateral optic neuritis, and an MRI of the spine shows longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis. Which of the following features helps differentiate this condition from multiple sclerosis?

choices.text: Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
Periventricular white matter plaques on MRI brain

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of painful eye movements, bilateral optic neuritis, and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LTEM) point is suggestive of Neuromyelitis optica. The presence of AQP4 antibodies in Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) helps to differentiate it from multiple sclerosis.

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is an auto-immune inflammatory disease that is characterized by the presence of antibodies directed against AQP4 (aquaporin 4). AQP-4 is localized to the foot processes of astrocytes in close proximity to endothelial surfaces.

The core clinical characteristics include

* Optic neuritis

* Longitudinally Extensive Transverse Myelitis (LETM)

* Area Postrema Syndrome (Unexplained hiccups/ nausea/ vomiting)

* Acute brainstem syndrome

* Symptomatic narcolepsy

* Acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD) - Typical diencephalic MRI lesions

* Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMSOD-typical brain lesions.

Attacks of optic neuritis are bilateral and severe in NMO, whereas in multiple sclerosis (MS) optic neuritis is usually unilateral. Progressive symptoms are not typical of NMO, unlike in MS. CSF findings in NMO show higher pleocytosis, with neutrophils and eosinophils in acute cases, and a rare occurrence of oligoclonal bands.

Acute attacks of NMO are treated with high-dose glucocorticoids. Plasma exchange can be used in acute attacks that do not respond to glucocorticoids.

Feature NMOSD Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
Optic Neuritis Bilateral, severe, poor recovery Unilateral, milder, better recovery
Spinal Cord Lesions Longitudinally extensive (≥3 vertebral segments), severe disability Short-segment lesions (<2 segments), milder disability
Brain Involvement Non-specific lesions associated with specific syndromes Periventricular white matter plaques
CSF Oligoclonal Bands Rare (<20%) Present (~90%)
AQP4 Antibodies Present Absent
Disease Course Relapsing, severe attacks leading to permanent disability Gradual progression, less severe attacks
Primary Immune Target Astrocytes Oligodendrocytes


Other options:

Option A: Oligoclonal bands are frequently seen in Multiple Sclerosis but are rare in NMOSD.

Option C: Acute attacks of both Multiple sclerosis and NMO response to high-dose steroids.

Option D: The presence of periventricular white matter plaques on MRI brain is characteristic of multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: 166. A post-stapedectomy patient complains of sudden onset of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating deafness. The symptoms aggravate on performing Valsalva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient suddenly developing vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating deafness post-stapedectomy, and worsening of symptoms with Valsalva is suggestive of perilymph fistula. 

A perilymph fistula is an abnormal connection between the inner and middle ear, leading to the leakage of perilymph from the cochlea or vestibule. This typically happens through the round or oval window. It can be caused by iatrogenic factors (eg. post-stapedectomy or ear surgery with stapes dislocation), as well as by head trauma and inner ear injuries resulting from forceful Valsalva maneuvers or barotrauma.

Patients with perilymph fistula typically present with intermittent vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. Symptoms can be triggered by the fistula test (intermittent pressure over the tragus) and the Valsalva maneuver. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the temporal bone is used for diagnosis. Initial treatment is conservative, including head elevation, bed rest, and avoiding activities that raise intracranial pressure. If symptoms continue or recur, exploratory tympanotomy may be indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Hemotympanum is the presence of blood in the middle ear. It can present with hearing loss, pain, and a feeling of fullness inside the ear. It is commonly associated with temporal bone fractures. 

Option C: Meniere disease can also present with vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating deafness. However, an iatrogenic history of post-stapedectomy makes perilymph fistula the more likely diagnosis. 

Option D: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome results from an abnormal connection between the semicircular canal and the brain. It occurs due to an abnormal thinness or incomplete closure of the bony canals in the inner ear. Patients can present with vertigo, tinnitus, autophony, and hearing loss. The iatrogenic history makes it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: 167. While performing Ziehl-Neelsen staining, you added the primary stain and sulphuric acid but are yet to add the counterstain. What will be the most likely result?

choices.text: Acid fast bacteria will be light pink and non acid fast bacteria will be red
Acid fast bacteria will be red and non acid fast bacteria will be light pink
Acid fast bacteria will be undetectable and non acid fast bacteria will be red
Both acid fast bacteria and non acid fast bacteria will be red

questions.solution:
While performing Ziehl-Neelsen staining, you added the primary stain and sulphuric acid but have yet to add the counterstain, so the acid fast bacteria will be red, and non-acid fast bacteria will be light pink. 

In Ziehl-Neelsen staining, acid-fast bacteria retain the primary stain (carbol fuchsin which is red in colour) even after being decolorized with sulphuric acid due to the presence of mycolic acid in their cell walls. Hence, with or without decolorization, they will still retain the red color of the primary stain.

Non-acid-fast bacteria lose the carbol fuchsin stain when washed with sulphuric acid, until only a light pink color remains. A properly decolorized slide appears light pink. Then, the counterstain (methylene blue) is added. 

The steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining are as follows: 

* The smear is initially stained with carbol fuchsin solution while applying heat.

* After staining, the smear is decolorized using 20% sulphuric acid (concentration differs for different organisms) and then counterstained with a contrasting dye, typically methylene blue.

* Acid fast bacteria retain the red color of carbol fuchsin, while non acid fast bacteria lose the primary stain and absorb the blue counterstain.

The image given below is a smear with Ziehl-Neelsen staining showing non-branching and acid-fast Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli.

questions.text:
168. A lady with 7 weeks of amenorrhea presented to the OPD with complaints of slight vaginal spotting. The TVS image revealed a MSD of 27 mm; however there was no embryo or cardiac activity in the present scan. The internal os is closed. What is the next best step in the management in this case?

TVS: Transvaginal ultrasound

MSD: Mean sac (gestational sac) diameter

CRL: Crown rump length
questions.solution:
The TVS revealing a MSD of 27 mm (Critical value ≥ 25 mm), with no embryo /cardiac activity indicates missed abortion. The next best step in management is to perform MTP.

In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, a gestational sac will be visible on TVS by 4.5-5 weeks of LMP, and at 5.5 weeks, the yolk sac appears. At 6 weeks, an embryo first appears adjacent to the yolk sac. The cardiac activity of the embryo can be first visualized on TVS around 6-6.5 weeks.

Mean sac (gestational sac) diameter ≥25mm and CRL ≥7mm are known as critical cut-off values, which represent the upper limit beyond which, if a structure is not visualized, it is abnormal.

Hence, missed abortion should be suspected if, on USG 

* CRL ≥7 mm, and no heartbeat is recorded (CRL-crown rump length)

* MSD ≥25 mm, and no embryo is seen (MSD-mean sac diameter)

Medical management can be performed with prostaglandin E1(misoprostol) or oxytocin. Surgical management in the form of dilatation and curettage can be performed.

questions.text: 170. A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy, on examination, was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz). But he has an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by the Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting the Meissner's corpuscles. 

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four types of mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

* Meissner corpuscles

* Merkel cells

* Ruffini corpuscles

* Pacinian corpuscles 

Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz). They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibrations. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm in length and 1mm in diameter. They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin. A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance. They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

questions.text: 171. Where is the type of joint shown in the image that shows movement in two perpendicular directions found?
questions.solution:
The image shows an ellipsoid joint, allowing movement in two perpendicular axes—flexion/extension and abduction/adduction—but no axial rotation. Radiocarpal joint (wrist joint) is an example of ellipsoid joint.

Other options:

Option A: The first carpometacarpal joint is a saddle joint, seen at the base of the thumb. It allows movement in two planes and permits limited axial rotation which is crucial for opposition of thumb.

Option C: The atlantoaxial joint is a pivot joint responsible for head rotation (e.g., shaking the head “no”).

Option D: The interphalangeal joint is a hinge joint that permits only flexion and extension.

questions.text: 172. A 62-year-old dialysis patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism presents with bone pain and a palpable mass in the femur. A bone biopsy reveals abnormal osteoid, bone marrow fibrosis, and hemorrhagic bone cysts. Which of the following clinical features is most consistent with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation, marked by bone pain, a palpable femoral mass, and a biopsy revealing abnormal bone matrix, fibrosis, and hemorrhagic cysts, is classic for brown tumors.

Brown tumors are a specific bone lesion indicative of severe hyperparathyroidism and osteitis fibrosa cystica. These tumors arise due to the high parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels seen in secondary hyperparathyroidism. Beyond brown tumors, severe hyperparathyroidism manifests with increased fracture risk, compression syndromes, and resistance to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs), partly due to bone marrow fibrosis. Furthermore, PTH itself acts as a uremic toxin, contributing to muscle weakness, cardiac muscle fibrosis, and systemic symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Osteomalacia results from diminished production or activity of 1,25(OH)2D3, causing the accumulation of unmineralized osteoid.

Option B: Adynamic bone disease is characterized by reduced bone formation and often linked to oversuppression of parathyroid hormone (PTH), and is distinct from the high-PTH state seen in this patient's secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Option D: Tumoral calcinosis is a recognized complication of adynamic bone disease which involves the deposition of calcium in soft tissues, forming large concretions.

questions.text: 173. Which of the following statements about the below instrument is not true?

choices.text: Its measurement is based on the Imbert-Fick principle.
Fluorescein dye staining of the eye can be done for this procedure.
Calculation is done by perfectly aligning two semicircular mires.
It provides accurate readings independent of corneal thickness.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Goldmann Applanation Tonometer. It does not provide accurate readings independent of corneal thickness.

Goldmann tonometer is an applanation tonometer used for the measurement of intraocular pressure. It works on the Imbert-Fick Principle (Option A)which states that the pressure inside an ideal, dry-walled sphere equals the force exerted on it divided by the area of flattening.

Pressure in sphere(IOP)= Force exerted on it(F)/Area of flattening(A)

This translates to the statement that intraocular pressure is dependent on the force exerted by the tonometer and the thickness of the cornea. The tonometer consists of a double prism which comes in contact with the cornea.

The steps of Applanation tonometry are as follows:

* Topical anesthetic and fluorescein are instilled into the conjunctival sac. (Option B)

* Patient positioned onto Slit lamp with forehead firmly pressed against the headrest.

* Cobalt blue filter applied, the dial is preset to 1, and the prism advanced until it touches the apex of the cornea.

* Slit lamp ocular viewing is used to horizontally and vertically center two semi-circular mires such that they are perfectly aligned. (Option C)

* The inner margin of the mires aligns when a circular area of diameter 3.06 mm is flattened. The reading obtained is multiplied by 10 to obtain the IOP in mmHg.

Some sources of error in IOP reading:

* Central corneal thickness must be around 520 micrometers with minimal variation. Thin corneas as seen after refractive surgeries or thick corneas as seen in ocular hypertension can falsely lower or increase IOP respectively.

* Thick mires due to overstaining with fluorescein and thin mires due to understaining cause overestimation and underestimation of IOP respectively.

* Eyelid squeezing, pressure on eyelids by fingers of examiner and restrictive ophthalmopathy (Thyroid) can cause falsely high IOP.

* Astigmatism can cause distortion of the mires and provide incorrect readings.

questions.text: 174. A male patient who presented with decreased vision is examined as shown in the image below. Which of the following value is measured by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure performed in the given image is A-scan ultrasonography. It is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball and can be done by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography).

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated by a biometer and the procedure is termed biometry.

The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK (Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff) formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where,

* P is the power of IOL.

* A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.

* L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.

* K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

The image given below shows a biometer.



The image below shows A scan ultrasonography for determining the axial length of the eyeball.



Option B: Corneal thickness is measured by pachymetry (image below).



Option C: Corneal curvature is measured by keratometry or opthalmometry (image below).



Option D: Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry (image below).

* Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness

* Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)

* Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness

* Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium

* Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: 175. An 8-year-old child presents with a history of morning headaches, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 6 months. MRI scan showed a contrast-enhancing nodule in the cerebellum. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. The tumors were positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a child presenting with symptoms of increased intra- cranial tension with an image that shows Rosenthal fibers is suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

On brain MRI, it can be identified as a contrast-enhancing nodule. On microscopy, it has very limited brain invasion compared to infiltrative astrocytomas. The tumor is made up of bipolar cells with hair-like projections forming a dense fibrillary meshwork. These cells are positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The characteristic features of this tumor are the presence of Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies. A Rosenthal fiber is a corkscrew-shaped eosinophilic inclusion while eosinophilic granular bodies are mulberry-shaped inclusions.

In low-grade astrocytoma, surgical resection is the primary treatment modality, and in the high-grade lesions, after surgical correction, local irradiation is also done.

The below image shows pilocytic astrocytoma with Rosenthal fibers (arrows) and dense fibrillary meshwork.



Other options:

Option A- Ependymomas are the tumors that arise from the ependyma-lined ventricular system. The tumor cells have fibrillary processes and form gland-like round or elongated structures (rosettes and canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a WHO grade IV aggressive tumor arising from the cerebellum. The tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: 176. A 24-year-old male undergoes evaluation for infertility. His semen analysis reveals a reduced number of mature sperm. A defect in spermiogenesis is suspected. Which of the following best describes the transformation of a spermatid during this process?

choices.text: It undergoes meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes
It differentiates into a mature spermatozoon without further division
It undergoes meiosis II to form spermatozoa
It divides mitotically to form primary spermatocytes

questions.solution:
Spermatids are haploid cells formed after meiosis II of secondary spermatocytes. They do not undergo further division but instead undergo spermiogenesis, a process where they mature into spermatozoa by developing a flagellum and acrosome and shedding excess cytoplasm.

Spermatogenesis is the process by which sperm are produced in the seminiferous tubules of the testes. It begins with spermatogonia (diploid stem cells), which undergo mitotic division to form primary spermatocytes. These primary spermatocytes enter meiosis I, producing secondary spermatocytes (haploid), which then undergo meiosis II to form spermatids. 

After meiosis, spermiogenesis occurs, during which spermatids mature into spermatozoa without further division. This process involves condensation of nuclear material, formation of the acrosome, development of the flagellum, and shedding of excess cytoplasm. The mature spermatozoa are then transported to the epididymis, where they gain motility and the ability to fertilize an ovum.



Other options: 

Option A: Primary spermatocytes undergo meiosis I to form secondary spermatocytes, not the spermatid. 

Option C: Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II to form spermatids, which further undergo spermiogenesis to form the spermatozoa

Option D: Type B spermatogonia undergo mitotic division to form primary spermatocytes

questions.text: 177. UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

Hanifin and Rajka proposed major and minor diagnostic criteria based on their clinical experience. Consequently, Williams et al. coordinated a UK working party to attempt to refine the criteria of Hanifin and Rajka into a repeatable and validated set of diagnostic criteria for atopic eczema.

Pearl PM0206: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

* Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)

* History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)

* History of a generally dry skin

* Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)

* Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: 179. Which of the following is the content of superior mediastinum?
questions.solution:
The right brachiocephalic vein is the content of the superior mediastinum.

The contents of the superior mediastinum are:

* Veins: Right and left brachiocephalic veins, upper half of the superior vena cava, left superior intercostal vein

* Nerves: Vagus, phrenic, cardiac nerves of both sides, left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

* Arteries: Arch of the aorta, brachiocephalic artery, left common carotid artery, left subclavian artery

* Trachea and oesophagus

* Origins of sternohyoid, sternothyroid, lower ends of longus colli muscles

* Thymus

* Thoracic duct

* Lymph nodes: Paratracheal, brachiocephalic, and tracheobronchial.



Other options:

Option A: Bifurcation of the trachea forms the anterior border of the posterior mediastinum.

questions.text: 180. Which of the following is not an advantage of the test shown below in diagnosing and managing various neoplasms?

choices.text: Assessment of multiple antigens simultaneously on the cell surface
Determination of origin of tumor cells

questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is immunohistochemistry. Assessment of multiple antigens simultaneously on the cell surface is not an advantage of immunohistochemistry staining.

Assessment of multiple antigens simultaneously on the cell surface is a property of flow cytometry, which uses a combination of specific antigens linked to fluorescent dyes. It is usually used for tumors arising from blood-forming tissues.

Immunohistochemistry is where specific antibodies identify surface markers or cell products. The following are the uses of immunohistochemistry -

* Categorisation of undifferentiated malignant tumor (Option A)—Tumor cells may have limited differentiation, which makes them difficult to identify on H&E slides. Antibodies directed against intermediate filaments are especially useful in these situations, since solid tumor cells typically express the particular intermediate filaments that reflect their tissue of origin. For example, cytokeratin, identified by immunohistochemistry, points to an epithelial origin, and desmin points to a muscle cell origin.

* Determination of origin of tumor (Option C)- in metastatic tumors where the primary site is not obvious. For example, PSA is specific for prostate cancer and thyroglobulin for thyroid cancer.

* Detecting antigen with therapeutic value (Option D) - ER/PR and Her2Neu detection in breast cancer for monitoring and prognosis.

questions.text: 181. A 16-year-old girl presents with nasal obstruction. She states that her friends make fun of her because she emits a bad odor. Physical examination reveals wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts and a pale nasal mucosa. Which of the following is not a component of the Kemicetine solution used in the management of this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with nasal obstruction, bad odor, wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. The Kemicetine solution used in the management of atrophic rhinitis contains chloramphenicol, estradiol, and vitamin D2. Phenylephrine is not a component of this solution.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic nasal inflammation associated with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis includes:

* Hereditary

* More commonly in females than males

* White and yellow races are more susceptible

* Nutritional deficiency- Deficiency of vitamin A, D, or iron

* Infective- Causative agents include Klebsiella ozaenae, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, etc.

* Autoimmune process

The clinical presentation of atrophic rhinitis includes nasal obstruction, foul smell from the nose with merciful anosmia, crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, and epistaxis.

Treatment

* Nasal irrigation and crust removal using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium bi-borate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water

* Local antibiotics - Kemicetine anti-ozaena solution contains chloramphenicol, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 

* 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

* Surgical management includes the modified Young's operation or narrowing the nasal turbinates.

Pearl PM1274: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

* Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family

* Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause

* Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races

* Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies

* Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa

* Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

* Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma

* Long-standing purulent sinusitis

* Radiotherapy to nose

* Excessive surgical removal of turbinates

* Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Pearl PM1275: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

* Symptoms:

* Foul smell from the nose

* Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity

* Epistaxis on removing of the crusts

* Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).

* Signs:

* Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum

* After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates

* Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: 182. A young patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, there was a loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the left lower limb. A provisional diagnosis of hemisection of the spinal cord was made. Lesions of which of the following structures are responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of hemisection of the spinal cord is suggestive of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Lesions of the left fasciculus gracilis are responsible for the observed findings.

Lesions of the fasciculus gracilis lead to the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral lower limb (fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally).

On the other hand, lesions of fasciculus cuneatus lesion will lead to loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral upper limb.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Pearl PM2382: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: 183. A patient presents with an inguinal hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an inguinal hernia lateral to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of an indirect hernia. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

The contents of an indirect hernia protrude laterally to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the internal inguinal ring obliquely towards the external inguinal ring and then reaches the scrotum. Whereas, the contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medially to the inferior epigastric artery and the internal inguinal ring.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used to repair a hernia are:

Bassini repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendons to the inguinal ligament. 

Shouldice repair is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.

Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia

McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.

Stoppa-Rives repair is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.

Herniotomy is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

questions.text: 184. A 42-year-old female presents with a 12-month history of chronic abdominal discomfort and infrequent bowel movements, characterized by hard, pellet-like stools. She reports significant straining during defecation and experiences relief of abdominal bloating after bowel movements. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is appropriate for the management of this subtype of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
This is a patient with constipation-predominant IBS (IBS-C) as the patient has infrequent, hard stools with straining during defecation. Lubiprostone is effective in the treatment of patients with IBS-C. 

Lubiprostone is a bicyclic fatty acid that activates type 2 chloride channels (ClC-2) in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells. In patients with constipation-predominant IBS (IBS-C), it is an effective treatment. Its side effects include nausea and diarrhea.

All other options (A) Rifaximin, (B) Diphenoxylate, and (D) Loperamide are used in diarrhea-predominant IBS.

Pearl PM2457: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

* Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine

* Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

* Opiate - Loperamide

* 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron

* Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

* Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol

* Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone

* Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide

* 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: 185. Which of the following committees is responsible for establishing the Medical and Health Education Commission?
questions.solution:
The Shrivastav committee recommended the establishment of a Medical and Health Education Commission for planning and implementing the reforms needed in health and medical education on the lines of the University Grants Commission.

The Shrivastav Committee was formed in the year 1975 as a “group on medical education and support manpower”. The committee was established for the following purposes:

* To devise a suitable curriculum for training a cadre of health assistants so that they can serve as a link between qualified medical practitioners and multipurpose workers

* To suggest steps for improving the existing medical educational processes so as to provide due emphasis on the problems particularly relevant to national requirements

The group recommended immediate action for the following: 

* Creation of bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers from within the community itself (e.g., school teachers, postmasters, gram-sevaks) to provide simple, promotive, preventive, and curative health services needed by the community

* Establishment of 2 cadres of health workers, namely multipurpose health workers and health assistants, between the community-level workers and doctors at the PHC

questions.text: 186. Given is an image of an infected tissue stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Which of the following is not true regarding the organism seen?

choices.text: Allergy following inhalation of airborne particles of the fungus
Colonization of tuberculous cavities in the lung
They proliferate in the walls of blood vessels cause infarction and necrosis of tissue.

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Aspergillus fumigatus.

It shows the characteristic feature of septate hyphae that branch at an acute angle of ~45 degrees. This fungus causes

* Invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients

* Aspergillomas in pre-existing lung cavities

* Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

Mucor, not Aspergillus, proliferate in the blood vessel wall. 

Mucor fungi

* They have irregular, broad, non-septate hyphae branching at wide angles.

* They cause diseases mostly in ketoacidosis diabetic and/or neutropenic patients.  

* Fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls, penetrate the cribriform plate, and enter the brain.

* They can cause rhinocerebral, frontal lobe abscess, and cavernous sinus thrombosis, which can manifest as headache; facial pain; black necrotic eschar on the face; and, sometimes, cranial nerve involvement.

questions.text: 187. The nucleus of which of the following cranial nerves is located deep to the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. 

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve. Columns are formed by groups of facial neurons, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurons innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature. 

The fourth ventricle is located between the brainstem and the cerebellum. The rhomboid fossa is a diamond-shaped depression seen on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The superior and the inferior parts of the floor are triangular in shape. It is divided by a longitudinal median sulcus into two halves. Each half is again divided into the medial and lateral regions.







Pearl PM2141: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain



Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

* III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  

* IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect

* V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 

* VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction

* IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   

* XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: 188. Which of the following molecular processes conflicts with the central dogma of molecular biology such that the protein encoded by the DNA and the product formed are not the same?
questions.solution:
RNA editing to form ApoB 48 conflicts with the central dogma of molecular biology as the protein coded by DNA (Apo-B100) and the product formed (Apo B48) are not the same.

The primary transcript encoded by the apolipoprotein B gene in the liver and intestine are the same. In the liver, this apolipoprotein B primary transcript is coded into ApoB100, a 100 kDa protein.

However, in the intestine, this primary transcript undergoes RNA editing whereby cytidine deaminase acts on the 48th codon to convert CAA to UAA , creating a stop codon and causing premature chain termination. Hence a different protein, ApoB48 is formed in the intestine.

The central dogma of molecular biology states that DNA undergoes replication to form new DNA, which in turn undergoes transcription to form mRNA, which in turn undergoes translation to form proteins.

Hence, proteins are formed based on the coding sequence present in the DNA. In RNA editing, an exception occurs where the gene for ApoB, instead of forming ApoB100 which it codes form, undergoes editing in the RNA stage to form a protein that is not coded for by the DNA.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of RNA editing followed by a schematic explaining the central dogma:





Other options: 

Option B: RNA silencing by RNA-induced silencing complex(RISC) is an example of RNA interference, a process by which double-stranded RNA is formed from a special RNA gene called mi-RNA gene(micro-RNA) and this RNA silences the complementary mRNA coding for a protein, by which translation does not occur. It is a cellular mechanism for gene silencing. The exact pathway is shown below:



Option C: Polyadenyl tail addition to RNA is a post-transcriptional modification. Other post-transcriptional modifications are endonuclease cleavage, 5' capping, methylation, removal of introns, and joining of exons by the spliceosome. The role of 3' polyadenylation with 25- 250 adenyl base pairs is to protect the mRNA from 3' exonuclease attack. A 5' cap is added to help the translation machinery identify the mRNA. 

The below image shows the steps of protein synthesis with post-transcriptional modifications:



Option D: Differential RNA processing is a form of increasing the genetic potential of the organism whereby a single mRNA is alternatively spliced into various combinations of exons, which can be combined to form various products.

This process is not considered an exception to central dogma as the protein formed and DNA encoding it are the same, only how exons are spliced changes. There is no new codon in the sequences formed, only the order and choice of codons transcribed changes.

questions.text: 189. The following are examples of enzyme inhibition. Based on the Lineweaver-Burk plots shown in the image, which one correctly matches the type of inhibition depicted in each graph?

choices.text: 1 - Statins inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase; 2 - Fluoride inhibiting enolase
1 - Methotrexate inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase; 2 - Phenylalanine inhibiting placental alkaline phosphatase
1 - Cyanide inhibiting cytochrome C oxidase; 2 - Statins inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase
1 - Ethanol inhibiting methanol metabolism by binding with alcohol dehydrogenase; 2 - Cyanide inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase

questions.solution:
Graph 1 represents non-competitive inhibition, and Graph 2 depicts competitive inhibition. Cyanide inhibiting cytochrome C oxidase is an example of non-competitive inhibition, and Statins inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase is an example of competitive inhibition.

Noncompetitive inhibition occurs when inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome noncompetitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the reaction's Vmax. They do not interfere with the substrate's binding to the enzyme, so the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts (due to decreased Vmax).



Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the addition of a competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same y-intercept (Vmax is unaffected) but different x-intercepts (due to increased Km).



Other options:

Option A: Statins inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase is an example of competitive inhibition. Fluoride acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of enolase by chelating magnesium and manganese ions, which are essential cofactors, thereby impairing glycolysis.

Option B: Methotrexate competitively inhibits DHFR. Phenylalanine inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase is an example of uncompetitive inhibition.

Option D: Ethanol inhibits methanol metabolism by binding with alcohol dehydrogenase, which is a competitive inhibition. Cyanide inhibits cytochrome c oxidase, which is a non-competitive inhibition.

questions.text: 190. A person falls and hits his shin against the edge of a metal bench. The resulting wound has sharp, gaping edges but irregular depth, along with bruising and tissue bridging. This wound is best classified as
questions.solution:
The wound is best classified as an incised-looking lacerated wound. 

The person hit their shin against the edge of a metal bench, which is not a sharp object like a knife but can act as a blunt force if struck with significant force. The wound has irregular depth, bruising, and tissue bridging which are clear signs of a laceration caused by blunt force, but also has sharp, gaping edges that mimics an incised wound. Hence incised-looking laceration is the best description for this wound. 

Incised-looking lacerated wounds are lacerations that occur without significant skin crushing and may have relatively sharp edges, giving them the appearance of an incised wound. When blunt force is applied to areas where the skin is stretched tightly over bone with minimal subcutaneous tissue, the resulting wound may form due to linear splitting of the skin, mimicking the appearance of an incised injury. 

Common locations for such wounds include the scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, lower jaw, iliac crest, perineum, and shin. Injuries caused by falls on flexed joints, such as the knee or elbow, or by impact with broken glass or sharp stones may result in lacerations that closely resemble incised wounds.

Option A: An incised wound is caused by a sharp-edged object and has clean, sharp, and well-defined margins without bruising or tissue bridging. The image below shows two spindle-shaped incisions:



Option B: A lacerated wound would have irregular and rough edges instead of sharp,gaping margins. Hence this makes incised-looking lacerated wound a more appropriate description of the wound.



Option D: A lacerated-looking incised wound is not a standard terminology, but can refer to an incised wound that looks like a laceration. It is usually caused by knife with serrated edges and are common in areas with skin folds like axilla and scrotum.

questions.text: 191. A patient with a road traffic accident(RTA) is sent to you for USG thorax suspecting a pneumothorax. You observe the following findings on USG. What mode of ultrasound did you use and what would be your advice to the accompanying doctor?

choices.text: M mode, nothing to be done
M mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest
B mode, insert a chest tube at the earliest

questions.solution:
The following image is a M-mode ultrasound showing seashore sign which suggests a normal lung and hence nothing needs to be done.

M-mode refers to motion mode. It gives the information about the motion of various structures over time in a small cross section.

On M-mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen: • Seashore sign: normal lung • Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax



The M-mode image in the pneumothorax demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign, indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign, and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

B mode USG refers to brightness mode. It shows two-dimensional images.

questions.text:
192. Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide(CO) called DLCO is measured as an index of diffusing capacity of the lung.

Reason: The transfer of CO is not limited by perfusion but by diffusion.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion. 

The diffusion capacity of the lungs is measured with carbon monoxide (CO) called DLCO because its uptake is diffusion-limited. Carbon monoxide (CO) is taken up by hemoglobin in the red blood cells at such a high rate that the partial pressure of CO in the capillaries stays very low. Blood usually stays for only 0.75 s in the pulmonary capillaries, and equilibrium is not reached in this. Therefore, at rest, the transfer of CO is not limited by perfusion but by diffusion. 

The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness.



In this test, a small amount of CO is used to measure the alveolar gas exchange during a 10-second breath-hold. The CO in exhaled breath is then analyzed and the quantity of CO that crosses the alveolar membrane is determined. The normal value of DLco at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

* Interstitial lung disease

* Emphysema (chronic bronchitis usually have normal DLCO)

DLCO is increased in patients with:

* Obesity

* Asthma

* Pulmonary hemorrhage

* Exercise

questions.text:
193. A chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with bladder carcinoma. A CT scan showed cancer infiltration into the muscular layer. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

TURBT: transurethral resection of bladder tumor

choices.text: Radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for bladder cancer involving the muscular layer (muscle-invasive bladder carcinoma) is radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection.

Cigarette smoking is the main aetiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes and schistosomiasis. Patients present with painless gross hematuria and frequency and urgency of urine.

Diagnosis is made using cystourethroscopy. Blue-light cystoscopy is better able to delineate the areas in the bladder with suspicion of malignancy. CT urogram is used to assess the upper urinary tract and the presence of hydroureteronephrosis. It is also used to assess lymph nodal metastases. MRI of the bladder is useful in assessing whether or not the muscle layer of the bladder is involved. 

Depending on the invasion of the lamina propria and muscularis propria layers, the staging and management of bladder cancer varies, as given below:

Non-invasive papillary urothelial cancer Does not involve the lamina propria

TURBT only; patients are followed up with cystoscopy
Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer It can involve lamina propria but does not invade the muscularis propria

TURBT followed by postoperative mitomycin C instillation

Multifocal and high-grade tumors may progress to muscle-invasive bladder cancer; radical cystectomy or intravesical BCG should be considered
Muscle-invasive bladder cancer Involves the muscularis propria

Radical cystectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy with urinary diversion

Radical external beam radiotherapy can be considered in patients unfit for surgery

questions.text: 194. Identify the test shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the given image is Adson's test done for thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome occurs due to compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus(C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels between the clavicle and the first rib. This produces neurological vascular symptoms. The compression can be due to an extra rib or due to abnormal scalene muscles, etc.

Clinical features:

Even though the anomalies responsible for this condition are congenital, symptoms appear during the third decade. This is because the blood vessels that supply the trunk level of the brachial plexus become less compliant in the third decade. 

The patient presents with pain and paresthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm and the medial two fingers. Ulnar clawing and wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the hand may be seen. Vascular signs are less common but the presence of unilateral Raynauds phenomenon should raise suspicion of thoracic outlet syndrome. 

Tests for thoracic outlet syndrome are provocative maneuvers that are performed to reproduce the signs and symptoms of this condition.

These provocative tests are not sensitive nor specific to making a diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Treatment:

Conservative management consists of shoulder muscle strengthening, postural training, and analgesics for pain.

Surgical management is indicated if there is severe pain, obvious muscle wasting, or presence of vascular disturbances. The cervical rib is removed via a supraclavicular or trans-axillary approach.

Pearl PM2041: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

* Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.

* Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 



Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.



Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.



Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: 195. A gastrointestinal smooth muscle was being studied. It was then subjected to electrical and mechanical recording. A trace of the recordings obtained is given below. What is the effect of acetylcholine and epinephrine on the number of spikes, respectively?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine increases and epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and the tension of the gastrointestinal smooth muscle.

The smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract have a basal electrical rhythm. The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65 mV and -45 mV. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the oesophagus and proximal stomach.

The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

* Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

* Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves.

questions.text: 196. An HIV-positive patient presents with 1 month of intermittent watery diarrhea. Stool saline wet mount and acid-fast stain of the organism are shown below, and it is found to be uniformly acid-fast. What is the first line of treatment for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with HIV presenting with intermittent watery diarrhea, stool saline wet mount, and acid-fast stain showing an oval, uniformly stained oocyst, with two sporocysts is suggestive of diarrhea due to isospora. The first line of treatment for this condition is cotrimoxazole. 

Diarrhea is a common complaint in patients with HIV. The infective agents implicated include mycobacterium avium complex, cytomegalovirus, and coccidian parasites like isospora, cyclospora, and cryptosporidium.

A comparison of these coccidian parasites is given in the table below:

The laboratory diagnosis for Isospora belli can be done by stool examination. Staining techniques are used as it is difficult to demonstrate the transparent oocyst in the saline wet mount preparation of stool. The techniques used are modified Ziehl Neelsen stain or Kinyoun acid-fast staining of stool smear. The below images show oocysts of cystoisospora in the modified acid-fast stain:

questions.text: 197. A 50-year-old patient presented with a growth on his face as seen in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be seen on biopsy?

choices.text: Large tumor cells with abundant cytoplasm and keratinisation
Nests of tumours cells with pagetoid spread
Small round cells with granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm

questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer) suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. Characteristic peripheral palisading of tumor cells is seen in this condition.

The image below shows tumors that resemble cells of the stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells (peripheral palisading of tumor cells).



Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a cancer of cells of the basal layer of the skin. It is the most common human cancer. Various clinical variants are seen but nodular basal cell carcinoma is the most common sub-type. It commonly presents on the head and neck as a flesh-colored mass. The lesion usually becomes more irregular as it grows.  

Management involves surgical excision with a predetermined margin. Complete clearance can be achieved in most cases of well‐defined small BCC with a 4–5 mm surgical margin.

Topical 5% imiquimod cream is also very effective in the treatment of BCC. It stimulates toll‐like receptors 7 and 8 which promote Th1 innate and adaptive cell‐mediated immune responses for recognition and destruction of the tumor cells.

Other options:

Option A: Large tumour cells with keratinisation showing invasion of the basement membrane of the epidermis are seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Tumour cells are usually large, polygonal with abundant cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei.



Option C: Nests of tumour cells with pagetoid (upward) spread are seen in malignant melanoma. It is very common in the nodular variant of melanoma where horizontal and vertical growth of tumour cells occurs.

Option D: Uniform small round cells having fine/granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm are seen in Merkel cell carcinoma, a neuroendocrine skin cancer. These cells are located in the epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions.

questions.text: 198. Following a reported snake bite, a patient shows up at the emergency department. Despite receiving medical treatment, the patient died. The patient's relatives bring a snake that they believe caused the bite, as seen in the picture. What is the probable cause of the patient's death?
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic. The probable cause of the patient's demise is respiratory paralysis.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia are the first signs of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases, the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

Other Options:

Option B and C: Venom from the Viperidae family of snakes (Pit Viper, Saw-scaled Viper) is vasculotoxic. Presentation can be as coagulopathy and hypovolemic shock due to widespread bleeding. 

Option D: Sea snake venom is myotoxic. The main presentation is generalised rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: 199. A middle-aged male from a remote village with no comorbidities requires prophylactic anticoagulation after orthopedic surgery. He mentions that he can return to the city only once in a few months as he does not have the finances to make regular appointments. Which of the following drugs can be given without regular coagulation monitoring?
questions.solution:
Apixaban can be given as an oral drug and does not require regular coagulation monitoring.

The given clinical scenario where a man with no comorbidities requires prophylaxis for venous thromboembolism after orthopedic surgery and cannot return regularly for follow-up mandates the need for an easy-to-take oral drug such as Apixaban. All the other drugs given require monitoring of the coagulation profile.

Apixaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitor. Rivaroxaban and edoxaban also belong to the same class of drugs. These drugs are given orally in fixed doses and do not require coagulation monitoring. The drugs affect PT more than apTT. However, anti-factor Xa assays provide the best estimate of anticoagulation if all monitoring is done. Annual RFT is mandated, and more frequent testing is also done in individuals with renal disease. Treatment indications include:

* Stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation

* Acute deep-vein thrombosis

* Acute pulmonary embolism

* Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in knee/hip arthroplasty

An important contraindication is stroke prevention in mechanical heart valves. They should also be avoided in APLA syndrome where warfarin is a better drug. The main adverse effect of these drugs is bleeding, which is not as severe or life-threatening as warfarin.

Other than apixaban, the other drugs cause increased GI bleeding. All drugs are substrates for p-glycoprotein and are metabolized by CYP3A4( except edoxaban) so plasma levels are reduced by inducers like Rifampicin, Phenytoin, etc. Andexanet alfa is the reversal agent for Apixaban and rivaroxaban.

Other options:

Option A: Unfractionated heparin requires regular aPTT monitoring. An aPTT value that is two or three times the normal value is considered therapeutic. Plasma heparin value of 0.3-0.7 units/mL as measured by anti-factor Xa assay is the therapeutic range for heparin. Activated clotting time test is used to monitor heparin in PCI and cardiac bypass surgery candidates.

Option C: Argatroban is a synthetic parenteral anticoagulant that binds reversibly to thrombin. Its primary indication is in prophylaxis and treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It causes an increase in both PT and aPTT and is monitored with both along with anti-Xa assays.

Option D: Desirudin is used for thromboprophylaxis in individuals undergoing hip surgery. It is a parenteral drug and requires daily creatinine and aPTT monitoring.

Pearl PM1655: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

200. The beneficiaries of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme are:

* Pregnant and nursing women

* Children younger than 3 years

* Children between 3 and 6 years of age

* Adolescent girls from 11 to 18 years old

* Other women between 15 and 45 years old
questions.solution:
All five statements with regard to the beneficiaries of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) are correct.

Integrated child development services was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing preschool non-formal education and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity, and mortality. Beneficiaries under the scheme are children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women, and lactating mothers among others.
